An emoji showing all fingers and thumb held together in a vertical orientation, often referred to as the Italian hand gesture ma che vuoi, sometimes called the "finger purse". In Italy this gesture tends to be used in disagreement, frustration, or disbelief and can mean “What do you want?” or “What are you saying?” Outside Italy anyone performing a caricature of an Italian person, regardless of context or tone, might use this gesture. Pinched Fingers has a variety of other culturally specific uses. In Israeli culture it can mean “hold on,” “relax,” or “be patient.” The K-Pop star Yuri uses it as a signature gesture to represent a dumpling and a general warm sentiment. It can also be used to represent the act of fisting. Not to be confused with 🤏 Pinching Hand, which has overlapping senses. Both are used to represent precision when someone is making a sharp point with accompanying speech. Pinched Fingers was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Pinched Fingers: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤌 Pinched Fingers and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinched Fingers: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Pinched Fingers: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤌 Pinched Fingers and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinched Fingers: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Pinched Fingers: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤌 Pinched Fingers and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinched Fingers: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Pinched Fingers: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤌 Pinched Fingers and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinched Fingers: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Pinched Fingers: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤌 Pinched Fingers and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinched Fingers: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A hand with thumb and index finger in close proximity. Used to suggest that something is small, or to gesture a small amount. Has Pinching Hand was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Pinching Hand: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤏 Pinching Hand and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinching Hand: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Pinching Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤏 Pinching Hand and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinching Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Pinching Hand: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤏 Pinching Hand and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinching Hand: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Pinching Hand: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤏 Pinching Hand and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinching Hand: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Pinching Hand: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤏 Pinching Hand and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pinching Hand: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

Most commonly known as a ✌️ Peace Sign, but traditionally called as a Victory Hand. Two fingers held up on one hand making a V sign. The reverse of this symbol is considered an offence gesture in British culture, similar to giving the middle finger. Victory Hand was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Victory Hand: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✌️ Victory Hand and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Victory Hand: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Victory Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✌️ Victory Hand and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Victory Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Victory Hand: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✌️ Victory Hand and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Victory Hand: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Victory Hand: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✌️ Victory Hand and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Victory Hand: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Victory Hand: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✌️ Victory Hand and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Victory Hand: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A fingers crossed emoji which displays the index (first) finger crossed over the middle (second) finger. Commonly used as a gesture indicating luck, or to show desire of a favorable outcome. This emoji is displayed with an additional finger on Samsung devices. Crossed Fingers was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Hand with Index and Middle Fingers Crossed” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Crossed Fingers: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤞 Crossed Fingers and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Crossed Fingers: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Crossed Fingers: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤞 Crossed Fingers and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Crossed Fingers: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Crossed Fingers: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤞 Crossed Fingers and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Crossed Fingers: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Crossed Fingers: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤞 Crossed Fingers and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Crossed Fingers: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Crossed Fingers: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤞 Crossed Fingers and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Crossed Fingers: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The gesture for “I love you” in American Sign Language, shown as a raised pinky (little) finger, index finger, and an extended thumb. Love-You Gesture was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “I Love You Hand Sign” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Love-You Gesture: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤟 Love-You Gesture and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Love-You Gesture: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Love-You Gesture: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤟 Love-You Gesture and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Love-You Gesture: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Love-You Gesture: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤟 Love-You Gesture and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Love-You Gesture: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Love-You Gesture: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤟 Love-You Gesture and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Love-You Gesture: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Love-You Gesture: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤟 Love-You Gesture and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Love-You Gesture: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A "rock on" hand gesture raising the pinky and index fingers on one hand, which a variety of other meanings. Sign of the Horns was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Sign of the Horns: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤘 Sign of the Horns and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Sign of the Horns: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Sign of the Horns: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤘 Sign of the Horns and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Sign of the Horns: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Sign of the Horns: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤘 Sign of the Horns and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Sign of the Horns: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Sign of the Horns: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤘 Sign of the Horns and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Sign of the Horns: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Sign of the Horns: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤘 Sign of the Horns and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Sign of the Horns: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A hand with thumb and little (pinky) finger extended, making a traditional phone-like shape. May be used in conjunction with a face to suggest “call me” (please). Not to be confused with the sign of the horn. Commonly used as a shaka sign, which is a similar gesture at a different orientation. Call Me Hand was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Call Me Hand: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤙 Call Me Hand and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Call Me Hand: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Call Me Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤙 Call Me Hand and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Call Me Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

Index finger pointing to the right. Backhand Index Pointing Right was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Right Pointing Backhand Index” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Index finger pointing upward, showing the back of the hand while doing so. Backhand Index Pointing Up was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Up Pointing Backhand Index” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Backhand Index Pointing Up: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👆 Backhand Index Pointing Up and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Backhand Index Pointing Up: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Backhand Index Pointing Up: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👆 Backhand Index Pointing Up and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Backhand Index Pointing Up: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A middle finger emoji, used in some western cultures as a rude or insulting gesture. The back of the hand is shown with the middle finger raised. Middle Finger was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Reversed Hand with Middle Finger Extended” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Middle Finger: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🖕 Middle Finger and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Middle Finger: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Middle Finger: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🖕 Middle Finger and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Middle Finger: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Middle Finger: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🖕 Middle Finger and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Middle Finger: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Index finger pointing downward. Backhand Index Pointing Down was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Down Pointing Backhand Index” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Backhand Index Pointing Down: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👇 Backhand Index Pointing Down and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Backhand Index Pointing Down: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Backhand Index Pointing Down: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👇 Backhand Index Pointing Down and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Backhand Index Pointing Down: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A single finger pointing upward, which could be used to represent the number one, or to ask a question. Index Pointing Up was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “White Up Pointing Index” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Index Pointing Up: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ☝️ Index Pointing Up and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Index Pointing Up: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Index Pointing Up: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ☝️ Index Pointing Up and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Index Pointing Up: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Index Pointing Up: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ☝️ Index Pointing Up and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Index Pointing Up: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Index Pointing Up: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ☝️ Index Pointing Up and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Index Pointing Up: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Index Pointing Up: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ☝️ Index Pointing Up and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Index Pointing Up: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
A thumbs-up gesture indicating approval. Thumbs Up was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Thumbs Up Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Up: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👍 Thumbs Up and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Up: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Up: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👍 Thumbs Up and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Up: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Up: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👍 Thumbs Up and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Up: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Up: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👍 Thumbs Up and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Up: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Up: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👍 Thumbs Up and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Up: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
A thumbs-down gesture indicating disapproval. Thumbs Down was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Thumbs Down Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Down: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👎 Thumbs Down and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Down: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Down: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👎 Thumbs Down and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Down: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Down: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👎 Thumbs Down and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Down: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Down: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👎 Thumbs Down and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Down: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Thumbs Down: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👎 Thumbs Down and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Thumbs Down: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A fist raised in the air that may be used as a celebratory gesture: the fist pump. Can also be used to represent zero items, due to a lack of any fingers being held up. Sometimes used as a symbol of resistance or defiance. Variations with darker skin tone are commonly used to represent the #BlackLivesMatter movement. Raised Fist was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Raised Fist: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✊ Raised Fist and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raised Fist: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Raised Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✊ Raised Fist and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raised Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A brown fist raised in the air, commonly used to represent the #BlackLivesMatter movement. The Raised Fist: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✊ Raised Fist and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raised Fist: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A dark brown fist raised in the air, commonly used to represent the #BlackLivesMatter movement. The Raised Fist: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✊ Raised Fist and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raised Fist: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A black fist raised in the air, commonly used to represent the #BlackLivesMatter movement. The Raised Fist: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✊ Raised Fist and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raised Fist: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A fist displayed in a position to punch someone, or to fist-bump another person. Shown as a right hand on all supported platforms. An equivalent left-handed version does not exist. Oncoming Fist was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Fisted Hand Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Oncoming Fist: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👊 Oncoming Fist and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Oncoming Fist: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Oncoming Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👊 Oncoming Fist and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Oncoming Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Oncoming Fist: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👊 Oncoming Fist and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Oncoming Fist: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Oncoming Fist: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👊 Oncoming Fist and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Oncoming Fist: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Oncoming Fist: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👊 Oncoming Fist and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Oncoming Fist: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A fist pointing left, which may be used in conjunction with the right-facing fist to complete a fist-bump gesture. Left-Facing Fist was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Left-Facing Fist: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤛 Left-Facing Fist and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Left-Facing Fist: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Left-Facing Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤛 Left-Facing Fist and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Left-Facing Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A fist pointing right, which may be used in conjunction with the left-facing fist to complete a fist-bump gesture. Right-Facing Fist was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Right-Facing Fist: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤜 Right-Facing Fist and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Right-Facing Fist: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Right-Facing Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤜 Right-Facing Fist and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Right-Facing Fist: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Right-Facing Fist: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤜 Right-Facing Fist and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Right-Facing Fist: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Right-Facing Fist: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤜 Right-Facing Fist and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Right-Facing Fist: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

Two hands clapping emoji, which when used multiple times can be used as a round of applause. Clapping Hands was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clapping Hands Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Clapping Hands: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👏 Clapping Hands and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Clapping Hands: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Clapping Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👏 Clapping Hands and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Clapping Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Clapping Hands: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👏 Clapping Hands and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Clapping Hands: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Clapping Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👏 Clapping Hands and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Clapping Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Clapping Hands: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👏 Clapping Hands and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Clapping Hands: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two hands raised in the air, celebrating success or another joyous event. Originally animated to show hands being raised, as might be done along with the the exclamation Banzai! in Japan. Now more commonly only shows the hands in the air. Raising Hands was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person Raising Both Hands in Celebration” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Raising Hands: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙌 Raising Hands and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raising Hands: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Raising Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙌 Raising Hands and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raising Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Raising Hands: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙌 Raising Hands and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raising Hands: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Raising Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙌 Raising Hands and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raising Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Raising Hands: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙌 Raising Hands and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Raising Hands: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two open hands, representing openness. Sometimes used as a hug, or as a display of jazz hands. Open Hands was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Open Hands Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Open Hands: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👐 Open Hands and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Open Hands: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Open Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👐 Open Hands and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Open Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Open Hands: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👐 Open Hands and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Open Hands: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Open Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👐 Open Hands and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Open Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Open Hands: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👐 Open Hands and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Open Hands: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two hands held out together with open palms facing up, in a slightly cupped manner. May be used to represent an open book in American Sign Language (ASL), or the gesture used by followers of Islam when praying. This gesture also appears similarly to one used to beg for for money. Palms Up Together was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Palms Up Together: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤲 Palms Up Together and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Palms Up Together: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Palms Up Together: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤲 Palms Up Together and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Palms Up Together: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Palms Up Together: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤲 Palms Up Together and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Palms Up Together: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Palms Up Together: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤲 Palms Up Together and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Palms Up Together: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Palms Up Together: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤲 Palms Up Together and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Palms Up Together: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

Two hands performing a handshake gesture, indicating a cordial greeting between friends or associates. Some platforms support a shared skin tone option for this emoji, though this is not standardized at present. Handshake was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

Two hands placed firmly together, meaning please or thank you in Japanese culture. A common alternative use for this emoji is for prayer, using the same gesture as praying hands. Rarely: a high-five. A previous version of this emoji displayed a yellow burst of light behind the two hands on iOS. Android once showed a blob-character with closed eyes and folded hands. Folded Hands was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person with Folded Hands” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Folded Hands: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙏 Folded Hands and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Folded Hands: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Folded Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙏 Folded Hands and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Folded Hands: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Folded Hands: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙏 Folded Hands and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Folded Hands: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Folded Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙏 Folded Hands and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Folded Hands: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Folded Hands: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙏 Folded Hands and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Folded Hands: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A right hand holding a pen or pencil and writing. Shown with a blue pen on all platforms except Apple which has a black pen. Writing Hand was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Writing Hand: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✍️ Writing Hand and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Writing Hand: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Writing Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✍️ Writing Hand and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Writing Hand: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Writing Hand: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✍️ Writing Hand and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Writing Hand: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Writing Hand: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✍️ Writing Hand and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Writing Hand: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Writing Hand: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining ✍️ Writing Hand and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Writing Hand: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Colored nail polish being applied to finger nails, often used to display an air of nonchalance or indifference. Shown as red, pink or purple nail polish on most platforms, the color rarely changes the meaning of this emoji. Previously displayed as a single bottle of nail polish on Android and on Windows. Nail Polish was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Nail Polish: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💅 Nail Polish and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nail Polish: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nail Polish: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💅 Nail Polish and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nail Polish: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nail Polish: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💅 Nail Polish and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nail Polish: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nail Polish: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💅 Nail Polish and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nail Polish: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nail Polish: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💅 Nail Polish and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nail Polish: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A mobile phone held up to take a selfie (photo of the person holding the phone or camera). Generally represented as a disembodied arm holding a mobile phone. Selfie was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Selfie: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤳 Selfie and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Selfie: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Selfie: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤳 Selfie and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Selfie: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Selfie: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤳 Selfie and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Selfie: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Selfie: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤳 Selfie and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Selfie: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Selfie: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤳 Selfie and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Selfie: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
An arm flexing to show its biceps muscle. Represents strength, or working out. Flexed Biceps was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Flexed Biceps: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💪 Flexed Biceps and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flexed Biceps: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Flexed Biceps: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💪 Flexed Biceps and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flexed Biceps: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Flexed Biceps: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💪 Flexed Biceps and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flexed Biceps: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Flexed Biceps: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💪 Flexed Biceps and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flexed Biceps: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Flexed Biceps: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💪 Flexed Biceps and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flexed Biceps: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
A mechanical or prosthetic arm. Mechanical Arm was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
A mechanical or prosthetic leg. Mechanical Leg was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
A human leg, shown detached from a human body. Displayed from the thigh and may include the foot. Leg was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Leg: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦵 Leg and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Leg: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Leg: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦵 Leg and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Leg: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Leg: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦵 Leg and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Leg: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Leg: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦵 Leg and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Leg: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
The Leg: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦵 Leg and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Leg: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A human foot shown with five toes and may include part or all of the ankle. Shown on Apple platforms as the sole of a foot. Foot was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Foot: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦶 Foot and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Foot: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Foot: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦶 Foot and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Foot: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Foot: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦶 Foot and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Foot: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Foot: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦶 Foot and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Foot: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Foot: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦶 Foot and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Foot: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
A single human ear. May be used in the context of listening, or hearing something. Ear was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Ear: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👂 Ear and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Ear: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👂 Ear and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Ear: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👂 Ear and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Ear: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👂 Ear and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
The Ear: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👂 Ear and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

An ear shown with a hearing aid, worn by a person with hearing loss. The style shown in Behind The Ear (BTE), but this can represent any form of hearing aid. Ear with Hearing Aid was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Ear with Hearing Aid: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦻 Ear with Hearing Aid and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear with Hearing Aid: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Ear with Hearing Aid: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦻 Ear with Hearing Aid and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear with Hearing Aid: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Ear with Hearing Aid: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦻 Ear with Hearing Aid and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear with Hearing Aid: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Ear with Hearing Aid: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦻 Ear with Hearing Aid and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear with Hearing Aid: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Ear with Hearing Aid: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦻 Ear with Hearing Aid and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ear with Hearing Aid: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
A human nose. May be used to indicate smelling, or something that smells. Nose was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Nose: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👃 Nose and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nose: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nose: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👃 Nose and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nose: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nose: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👃 Nose and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nose: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nose: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👃 Nose and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nose: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Nose: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👃 Nose and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Nose: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
Brain was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
Anatomical Heart was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Lungs was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Tooth was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
A bone which may be used for a dog to chew on, or as a part of the human body. The type of bone is not specified. Bone was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A pair of eyes, glancing slightly to the left on most platforms. The Google version of this emoji previously showed only a single eye, despite the name of this character being eyes (plural). Sometimes used to indicate ‘pervy eyes’ to indicate approval of an attractive photo posted online; or ‘shifty eyes’ to convey a deceitful act. Eyes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A single human eye, looking forward. This eye is in a different shape and style to the pair of eyes, which are more rounded, and looking to one side. Eye was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A tongue, sticking out. May be used as a childish sign of defiance. Tongue was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A human mouth which is generally displayed as a pair of lips and a top row of teeth, instead of the inside of the mouth. May be used to indicate the spoken word or as an alternative to Kiss Mark. Mouth was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The face of a young infant (baby). Shows the face of a baby with a small amount of hair on most platforms, while some variations show a pacifier (dummy) in its mouth. Android previously displayed this emoji as a swaddled baby. On Snapchat, the baby emoji signifies a new friend on the service. Baby was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Baby: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👶 Baby and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👶 Baby and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👶 Baby and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👶 Baby and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👶 Baby and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
A child with no gender specified. This may be used as a gender-inclusive alternative to the boy or girl emoji. Child was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Child: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧒 Child and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Child: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Child: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧒 Child and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Child: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Child: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧒 Child and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Child: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Child: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧒 Child and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Child: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Child: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧒 Child and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Child: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The face of a boy, smiling. Previously differentiated from the man emoji on Android by wearing a cap, and on iOS by the lack of any facial hair. Boy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Boy: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👦 Boy and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Boy: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Boy: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👦 Boy and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Boy: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Boy: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👦 Boy and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Boy: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Boy: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👦 Boy and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Boy: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
The Boy: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👦 Boy and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Boy: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The face of a girl, smiling. Differentiated from the woman emoji by the hairstyle which features pigtails which are not present on the woman. Girl was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Girl: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👧 Girl and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Girl: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Girl: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👧 Girl and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Girl: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Girl: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👧 Girl and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Girl: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Girl: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👧 Girl and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Girl: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Girl: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👧 Girl and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Girl: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

An adult with no gender specified. This may be used as a gender-inclusive alternative to the man or woman emoji. Person was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Adult” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧑 Person and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧑 Person and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧑 Person and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧑 Person and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧑 Person and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A person with blond hair, which tends to appear as yellow. Displayed as a man on all platforms, this emoji keeps blond hair no matter which skin tone is chosen. Previous releases showed this emoji as a woman on Android, Windows, and Samsung. Person: Blond Hair was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person with Blond Hair” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person: Light Skin Tone, Blond Hair emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👱 Person: Blond Hair and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Light Skin Tone, Blond Hair was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Blond Hair emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👱 Person: Blond Hair and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Blond Hair was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person: Medium Skin Tone, Blond Hair emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👱 Person: Blond Hair and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium Skin Tone, Blond Hair was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Blond Hair emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👱 Person: Blond Hair and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Blond Hair was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person: Dark Skin Tone, Blond Hair emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👱 Person: Blond Hair and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Dark Skin Tone, Blond Hair was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
A man of adult age, shown on some platforms with a moustache. Man was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Man: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👨 Man and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👨 Man and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Man: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👨 Man and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Man: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👨 Man and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
The Man: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👨 Man and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A person with a visible beard. Generally displayed with a masculine appearance, though intended to be gender neutral from 2021. New gender-specific options for a woman with a beard or man with a beard are drafted for Emoji 13.1. Person: Beard was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Bearded Person” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Light Skin Tone, Beard emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧔 Person: Beard and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Light Skin Tone, Beard was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Beard emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧔 Person: Beard and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Beard was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Medium Skin Tone, Beard emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧔 Person: Beard and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium Skin Tone, Beard was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Beard emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧔 Person: Beard and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Beard was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Person: Dark Skin Tone, Beard emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🧔 Person: Beard and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person: Dark Skin Tone, Beard was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A man with red hair. Sometimes described as ginger, orange, copper, or auburn. The Man: Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Light Skin Tone, Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Light Skin Tone, Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Medium Skin Tone, Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏽 Medium Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium Skin Tone, Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Dark Skin Tone, Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏿 Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Dark Skin Tone, Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Light Skin Tone, Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Light Skin Tone, Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Medium Skin Tone, Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏽 Medium Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium Skin Tone, Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man: Medium-Dark Skin Tone, Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

An older adult with no gender specified. This may be used as a gender-inclusive alternative to the older man or older woman emoji. Older Person was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Older Adult” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A person with a serious expression, showing mild displeasure with the situation. Could be considered to be reserved or stoic in response, as this person is not visible angry. Quite different to the Pouting Face Emoji which conveys a more aggressive tone, and is a smiley. Pouting Cat Face is a cat. Person Pouting was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person with Pouting Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A person with arms crossed forming an ‘X’ to indicate ‘no’ or ‘no good’. This motion is used on the TV game show Deal or No Deal to indicate ‘No Deal’. Person Gesturing No was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Face with No Good Gesture” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A person with arms above her or his head, making an ‘OK’ sign (circle) with the whole body. No gender is specified, but this emoji is generally shown as a woman. A person tipping their hand by their shoulder as if they’re carrying a tray of drinks or flipping their hair. Originally called Information Desk Person. This emoji is commonly used to express sassiness or sarcasm. While no gender is specified, many early designs displayed this emoji as a woman. Google’s 2014 design shows a blob wearing white gloves and a pillbox hat. Microsoft’s 2015 design shows a woman doing this gesture while winking, a facial expression that further reinforces the sassy and sarcastic uses of this emoji. Person Tipping Hand was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Information Desk Person” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person Tipping Hand: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💁 Person Tipping Hand and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Tipping Hand: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Tipping Hand: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💁 Person Tipping Hand and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Tipping Hand: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A person bowing deeply which is known as dogeza in Japan. Used to express a sincere apology, or to request a large favour. Many variations of this emoji are misinterpreted as a person doing push-ups, lying down to have a massage, or doing a cute "head resting on hands" gesture. Person Bowing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person Bowing Deeply” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person Bowing: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🙇 Person Bowing and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Bowing: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A hand shown pressing against the head of a person, commonly written as facepalm. Used to display frustration or embarrassment at the ineptitude of a person or situation. May be used in a similar context to the acronym SMH (shaking my head), or in relation to the Picard Facepalm meme. Person Facepalming was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Face Palm” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A person shrugging their shoulders to indicate a lack of knowledge about a particular topic, or a lack of care about the result of a situation. Displays as raised shoulders, sometimes in conjunction with raised arms and flat hands. The shrug gesture in text (emoticon / kaomoji) form is known as a shruggie and typed as: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ The Unicode character Shrug ("Person Shrugging") does not specify a gender. See also Woman Shrugging or Man Shrugging. Person Shrugging was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Shrug” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

An undercover investigator, wearing a hat, and sometimes using a magnifying glass to closely inspect evidence. This emoji did not originally recommend emoji modifiers, but a proposal was created to address this. Detective was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Sleuth or Spy” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Woman Detective: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🕵️ Detective, 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀️ Female Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Detective: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Woman Detective: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🕵️ Detective, 🏽 Medium Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀️ Female Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Detective: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A British guardsman, known as a foot guard. Wears a tall black hat with a yellow chin-strap. Must look straight ahead at all times, even when tourists attempt to distract them. Guard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Guardsman” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Guard: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💂 Guard and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Guard: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Guard: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💂 Guard and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Guard: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Ninja: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🥷 Ninja and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Ninja: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A construction worker wearing a hard-hat (safety helmet). Has a high visibility vest or hammer in some variations. Some platforms display a green cross on the helmet which is used in Japan as a safety reminder in construction zones. It is also commonly seen on the Met helmet in the game Mega Man. Construction Worker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Construction Worker: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👷 Construction Worker and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Construction Worker: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Male royalty, intended as a gender pair for the princess emoji. Shown as a man with a crown. Not a reference to the musician Prince, however the man singer emoji on WhatsApp does show a character that bears a heavy resemblance to this artist. Prince was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Prince: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤴 Prince and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Prince: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The face of a princess; a girl or woman wearing a small crown or tiara. Could also be used to represent a Queen or other royalty. Princess was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A person wearing a gua pi mao; a type of Chinese hat. Sometimes referred to as a skullcap. Person With Skullcap was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Man with Gua Pi Mao” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person With Skullcap: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👲 Person With Skullcap and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person With Skullcap: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A person (generally depicted as a woman) wearing a headscarf. While the type of  headscarf is not specified, this is most commonly displayed as a woman wearing a hijab. Woman with Headscarf was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Person with Headscarf” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Man with Veil: Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👰 Person With Veil, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man with Veil: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A pregnant woman, intended to complete the family emoji set. Sometimes used in jest to represent feeling full after over-eating; aka "food baby". Pregnant Woman was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Pregnant Woman: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤰 Pregnant Woman and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pregnant Woman: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Pregnant Woman: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤰 Pregnant Woman and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pregnant Woman: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Pregnant Woman: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤰 Pregnant Woman and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pregnant Woman: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Pregnant Woman: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤰 Pregnant Woman and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pregnant Woman: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Pregnant Woman: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤰 Pregnant Woman and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pregnant Woman: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A woman shown breastfeeding a baby, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling. This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the mother. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the mother. See 🧑‍🍼 Person Feeding Baby for bottle feeding instead of breastfeeding. Breast-Feeding was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Breast-Feeding: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤱 Breast-Feeding and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Breast-Feeding: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Breast-Feeding: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤱 Breast-Feeding and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Breast-Feeding: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Breast-Feeding: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤱 Breast-Feeding and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Breast-Feeding: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Breast-Feeding: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤱 Breast-Feeding and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Breast-Feeding: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Breast-Feeding: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤱 Breast-Feeding and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Breast-Feeding: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A woman feeding a baby with a bottle, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling. This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the adult. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the adult. Variants include 🧑‍🍼 Person Feeding Baby and 👨‍🍼 Man Feeding Baby. See also 🤱 Breast-Feeding. The Woman Feeding Baby emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Feeding Baby was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Woman Feeding Baby: Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Feeding Baby: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Woman Feeding Baby: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Feeding Baby: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Woman Feeding Baby: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, 🏽 Medium Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Feeding Baby: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Woman Feeding Baby: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Feeding Baby: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Woman Feeding Baby: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, 🏿 Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Feeding Baby: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Feeding Baby was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Person Feeding Baby: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Feeding Baby: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

An angelic baby with wings, and a halo above its head. Commonly known as a cherub. Baby Angel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Baby Angel: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👼 Baby Angel and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby Angel: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby Angel: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👼 Baby Angel and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby Angel: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby Angel: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👼 Baby Angel and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby Angel: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby Angel: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👼 Baby Angel and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby Angel: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Baby Angel: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👼 Baby Angel and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Baby Angel: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Santa Claus, sometimes referred to as Father Christmas, brings joy to children at Christmas time. Displayed with a beard and red festive hat. The Santa emoji had a frown on Android 4.4, which was resolved in Android 5.0. See also: Christmas emoji list. Note: Father Christmas has a different origin to Santa Claus but both are represented by this single emoji. Santa Claus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Father Christmas” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Santa Claus: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🎅 Santa Claus and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Santa Claus: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Santa Claus: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🎅 Santa Claus and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Santa Claus: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Santa Claus: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🎅 Santa Claus and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Santa Claus: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Santa Claus: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🎅 Santa Claus and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Santa Claus: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Santa Claus: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🎅 Santa Claus and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Santa Claus: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Mother Christmas, more commonly known as Mrs. Claus, is the wife of Santa Claus. Displayed as an older woman with glasses and a festive red and white bonnet. See also: Christmas emoji list. Mrs. Claus was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Mother Christmas” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Mrs. Claus: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤶 Mrs. Claus and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mrs. Claus: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Mrs. Claus: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤶 Mrs. Claus and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mrs. Claus: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Mrs. Claus: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤶 Mrs. Claus and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mrs. Claus: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Mrs. Claus: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤶 Mrs. Claus and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mrs. Claus: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Mrs. Claus: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🤶 Mrs. Claus and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mrs. Claus: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

An older person wearing a red Christmas (aka "Santa") hat. Does not represent any specific character in folklore. Mx Claus provides a gender inclusive alternative to 🎅 Santa Claus or 🤶 Mrs. Claus. Mx is an honorific that does not indicate gender. The Mx Claus emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎄 Christmas Tree. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mx Claus was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Mx Claus: Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎄 Christmas Tree. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mx Claus: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Mx Claus: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎄 Christmas Tree. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mx Claus: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Mx Claus: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏽 Medium Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎄 Christmas Tree. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mx Claus: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Mx Claus: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎄 Christmas Tree. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mx Claus: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The Mx Claus: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏿 Dark Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎄 Christmas Tree. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Mx Claus: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A hero which may be displayed as a man,woman or gender-neutral / gender-inclusive depending on the platform. This base emoji does not specify a gender, but is used to create the emojis for Man Superhero and Woman Superhero. The Supervillain is the nemesis of this emoji. Superhero was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Superhero: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦸 Superhero and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Superhero: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Superhero: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦸 Superhero and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Superhero: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Superhero: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦸 Superhero and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Superhero: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
