The Superhero: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🦸 Superhero and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Superhero: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man Superhero emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🦸 Superhero, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Superhero was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The Man Superhero: Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🦸 Superhero, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Superhero: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A reanimated human, often found in works of horror fiction. May have a female or male appearance. Zombie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
The Man Zombie emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧟 Zombie, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Zombie was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The Woman Zombie emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧟 Zombie, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀️ Female Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Zombie was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A person getting his or her face massaged. Apple’s artwork for this character shows more of a head massage. Google and Microsoft display a more accurate face massage, with hands rubbing the cheeks and face. Person Getting Massage was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Face Massage” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person Getting Massage: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💆 Person Getting Massage and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Getting Massage: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Getting Massage: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💆 Person Getting Massage and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Getting Massage: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The male version of the 💆 Face Massage emoji. The Man Getting Massage emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💆 Person Getting Massage, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Getting Massage was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A person in the process of getting their hair cut. This emoji is intended to be gender-neutral, but is commonly shown as a girl or woman smiling, with scissors shown open next to the hair on her head. Windows previously displayed this emoji as a comb and scissors, instead of a person having their hair cut. Person Getting Haircut was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Haircut” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person Getting Haircut: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💇 Person Getting Haircut and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Getting Haircut: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A person going for a walk. Taking a slow-medium pace, this person would be a runner if they picked up their speed. This emoji does not specify a gender, but is shown as a man on most major platforms. Person Walking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Pedestrian” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A person standing upright. May be used to represent human in a general sense, or shown in sequence to imply holding hands. Similar in appearance to 🚶 Person Walking, but shown facing forward and without any motion implied. Person Standing was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Standing Person” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A person running, with a large stride and arms outstretched. May be wearing a running shirt. This emoji does not specify a gender, but is shown as a man on most platforms. See also: 🏃‍♀️ Woman Running or 🏃‍♂️ Man Running. Person Running was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Runner” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person Running: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🏃 Person Running and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Running: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Running: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🏃 Person Running and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Running: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Running: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🏃 Person Running and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Running: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The male version of the 🏃 Runner emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji. Man Running was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A person dancing, most commonly displayed as woman with one arm raised wearing a red dress, while dancing the salsa or flamenco. Often used to represent a sense of fun or as a positive affirmation, e.g. "great! 💃" This emoji did not originally specify a gender, but was canonically deemed a woman when the 🕺 Man Dancing emoji was approved. Google previously displayed this emoji as a man, then a gender-neutral blob character (in keeping with guidelines at the time). Microsoft previously displayed this emoji as stick figure, and Samsung has displayed this over various releases as a white boy, black boy, and white girl. Woman Dancing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dancer” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Woman Dancing: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💃 Woman Dancing and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Dancing: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Woman Dancing: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💃 Woman Dancing and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Dancing: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Woman Dancing: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💃 Woman Dancing and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Dancing: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Woman Dancing: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💃 Woman Dancing and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Dancing: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Woman Dancing: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 💃 Woman Dancing and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman Dancing: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A man dancing, added as a gender pair for the 💃 Woman Dancing. Shown on most platforms in a 70s-era suit, and one hand in the air in a disco-dancing style. Man Dancing was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Man Dancing: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕺 Man Dancing and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Dancing: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Man Dancing: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕺 Man Dancing and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Dancing: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Man Dancing: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕺 Man Dancing and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Dancing: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Man Dancing: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕺 Man Dancing and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Dancing: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Man Dancing: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕺 Man Dancing and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Man Dancing: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A person wearing a suit, hovering above the ground with a shadow displayed beneath them. Generally shown wearing a fedora or similar style of hat. This character was originally introduced into the Webdings font as an “exclamation mark in the style of the rude boy logo found on records by The Specials". This levitating man was known as Walt Jabsco. Person in Suit Levitating was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Man in Business Suit Levitating” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person in Suit Levitating: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕴️ Person in Suit Levitating and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Suit Levitating: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Suit Levitating: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕴️ Person in Suit Levitating and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Suit Levitating: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Suit Levitating: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕴️ Person in Suit Levitating and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Suit Levitating: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Suit Levitating: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕴️ Person in Suit Levitating and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Suit Levitating: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Suit Levitating: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🕴️ Person in Suit Levitating and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Suit Levitating: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

An iteration of the Playboy Bunny known in Japan as a Bunny Girl. Usually depicted as an attractive woman  wearing bunny ears; a bunny girl can also be seen in anime as a hybrid human/animal known as Kemonomimi. Some versions of this emoji, such as Apple’s, display two girls dancing, each wearing a leotard and bunny ears. Other interpretations show the face of one woman wearing bunny ears. The two-person version of this emoji is often used as a display of friendship, fun, or "let's party". People with Bunny Ears was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Woman with Bunny Ears” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The male version of the 👯 Woman With Bunny Ears emoji. The Men with Bunny Ears emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👯 People with Bunny Ears, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Men with Bunny Ears was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A female version of the 👯 People With Bunny Ears emoji. The Women with Bunny Ears emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👯 People with Bunny Ears, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀️ Female Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Women with Bunny Ears was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A person in a sauna, holding a ladle for pouring water on hot stones, which creates the steamy environment. Popular in Finland, where people sauna in the nude. Person in Steamy Room was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A jockey riding a horse in a horse race. Shown riding to the left of screen on all major platforms. Emoji modifiers change the skin tone of the jockey on some platforms, which can be difficult to discern at small sizes. Horse Racing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Horse Racing: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🏇 Horse Racing and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Horse Racing: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

Skin tones support is not recommended for this emoji, but this is supported by some platforms. Skier was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A gender-unspecified person taking a soothing bath in a white tub with a shower head. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally. May also represent relaxation and self-care. The appearance of the person, depicted in default yellow, varies. Apple's person is wearing a green shower cap, WhatsApp's a green washcloth. Google’s person appears to be playing in a bubble bath, with soapsuds atop their ahead. Other major vendors show the head of the bather with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone modifiers are available on supported platforms. Vendors implement the same or a similar tub and shower head as for their 🛁 Bathtub, but with a person taking/having a bath. Person Taking Bath was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bath” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person Taking Bath: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛀 Person Taking Bath and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Taking Bath: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Taking Bath: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛀 Person Taking Bath and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Taking Bath: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Taking Bath: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛀 Person Taking Bath and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Taking Bath: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Taking Bath: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛀 Person Taking Bath and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Taking Bath: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

The Person Taking Bath: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛀 Person Taking Bath and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person Taking Bath: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A bed with a gender-unspecified person sleeping in it, as at a house, hotel, hostel, or other sleeping accommodation. Used especially for various content concerning sleeping as well as beds, furniture, housing, relaxing, and other bedroom activities. Shown with a headboard at the left and footboard with a person under the covers, head on the pillow. Most platforms suggest a wooden frame and feature blue or red sheets. The appearance of the person varies. Apple and Facebook's designs show only the hair of the sleeper, Apple's black and Facebook's brown and tousled. Other major vendors show the head of the sleeper in default yellow with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone support is not recommended for this emoji, though it is supported on some platforms. Vendors implement the same style of bed as for their 🛏️ Bed, but with a sleeper in it. Person in Bed was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Sleeping Accommodation” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Person in Bed: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛌 Person in Bed and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Bed: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Bed: Medium-Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛌 Person in Bed and 🏼 Medium-Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Bed: Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Bed: Medium Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛌 Person in Bed and 🏽 Medium Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Bed: Medium Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Bed: Medium-Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛌 Person in Bed and 🏾 Medium-Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Bed: Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Person in Bed: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 🛌 Person in Bed and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Person in Bed: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

Two people holding hands, most likely due to being in a relationship. No gender is specified for these two people, meaning they are likely to be shown with a gender inclusive design. The People Holding Hands emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 🤝 Handshake, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🧑 Person. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. People Holding Hands was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The People Holding Hands: Light Skin Tone emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person, 🏻 Light Skin Tone, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 🤝 Handshake, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 🧑 Person and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. People Holding Hands: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman and Man Holding Hands: Dark Skin Tone, Medium-Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

The Woman and Man Holding Hands: Dark Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👫 Woman and Man Holding Hands and 🏿 Dark Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Woman and Man Holding Hands: Dark Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Two men holding hands, most likely due to being in a relationship. Men Holding Hands was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Two Men Holding Hands” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Men Holding Hands: Light Skin Tone emoji is a modifier sequence combining 👬 Men Holding Hands and 🏻 Light Skin Tone. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Men Holding Hands: Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Men Holding Hands: Light Skin Tone, Medium-Light Skin Tone was added to Emoji 12.1 in 2019.

A kissing gesture, shown with a pink love heart floating in the air between two people. No gender is specified for the two people, and as such this may be used to represent the concept of a couple broadly, and/or as a means of showing two non-binary people. Previously shown with the same appearance as 👩‍❤️‍💋‍👨 Kiss: Woman, Man, but now displays two people with an ambiguous gender appearance. Kiss was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Kiss: Woman, Man emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, ❤️ Red Heart, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 💋 Kiss Mark, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👨 Man. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Kiss: Woman, Man was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two men displayed kissing, or gesturing a kiss toward each other. At small sizes this may be difficult to discern from the two women kissing. The Kiss: Man, Man emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, ❤️ Red Heart, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 💋 Kiss Mark, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👨 Man. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Kiss: Man, Man was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two women displayed kissing, or gesturing a kiss toward each other. At small sizes this may be difficult to discern from two men kissing. The Kiss: Woman, Woman emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, ❤️ Red Heart, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 💋 Kiss Mark, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👩 Woman. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Kiss: Woman, Woman was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A couple standing next to each other, smiling, with a pink love heart floating in the air between them. No gender is specified for the two people, and as such this may be used to represent the concept of a couple broadly, and/or as a means of showing two non-binary people. Previously shown with the same appearance as 👩‍❤️‍👨 Couple With Heart: Woman, Man, but now displays two people with an ambiguous gender appearance. Couple with Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Couple with Heart: Woman, Man emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, ❤️ Red Heart, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👨 Man. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Couple with Heart: Woman, Man was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two men standing next to each other, smiling, with a pink love heart floating in the air between them. The Couple with Heart: Man, Man emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, ❤️ Red Heart, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👨 Man. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Couple with Heart: Man, Man was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

Two women standing next to each other, smiling, with a pink love heart floating in the air between them. The Couple with Heart: Woman, Woman emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, ❤️ Red Heart, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👩 Woman. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Couple with Heart: Woman, Woman was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family unit shown with two adults and one child. Previously displayed with the same design as 👨‍👩‍👦 Family: Man, Woman, Boy on most platforms, but now has its own gender inclusive appearance. Family was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Family: Man, Woman, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Woman, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with a father, mother, and one daughter. The Family: Man, Woman, Girl emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👧 Girl. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Woman, Girl was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with a father, mother, daughter, and son. The Family: Man, Woman, Girl, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👧 Girl, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Woman, Girl, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with a father, mother, and two sons. The Family: Man, Woman, Boy, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👦 Boy, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Woman, Boy, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with a father, mother, and two daughters. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Woman, Girl, Girl was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two fathers, and one son. The Family: Man, Man, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Man, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two fathers, and one daughter. The Family: Man, Man, Girl emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👧 Girl. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Man, Girl was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two fathers, one daughter, and one son. The Family: Man, Man, Girl, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👧 Girl, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Man, Girl, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two fathers, and two sons. The Family: Man, Man, Boy, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👦 Boy, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Man, Boy, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two fathers, and two daughters. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Man, Girl, Girl was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two mothers, and one son. The Family: Woman, Woman, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Woman, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two mothers, and one daughter. The Family: Woman, Woman, Girl emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👧 Girl. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Woman, Girl was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two mothers, one daughter, and one son. The Family: Woman, Woman, Girl, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👧 Girl, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Woman, Girl, Boy was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.

A family with two mothers, and two sons. The Family: Woman, Woman, Boy, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👦 Boy, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. A family with two mothers, and two daughters. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Woman, Girl, Girl was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
The Family: Man, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Boy was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Family: Man, Boy, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👦 Boy, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Man, Boy, Boy was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Family: Woman, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Boy was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Family: Woman, Boy, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👦 Boy, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Boy, Boy was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Family: Woman, Girl emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👧 Girl. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Girl was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Family: Woman, Girl, Boy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👧 Girl, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👦 Boy. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Girl, Boy was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Family: Woman, Girl, Girl emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman, ‍ Zero Width Joiner, 👧 Girl, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👧 Girl. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Family: Woman, Girl, Girl was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The silhouette of a person speaking. Faces left-to-right, with lines demonstrating speech being expelled. Sometimes used in the context of shouting or mansplaining. Speaking Head was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Speaking Head in Silhouette” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Generic profile of one person. Often used in interface design to represent a user. Bust in Silhouette was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Generic profile of two people. Often used in interface design to represent users. Busts in Silhouette was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two people hugging, shown in a design that doesn't show specific details of either individual. Representing a clearer hug gesture than the existing 🤗 Hugging Face. People Hugging was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Two human footsteps,  showing the outline of both feet, including all five toes. Footprints was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a monkey, looking straight ahead. Depicted as a brown-haired monkey with a tan or pinkish face, round ears, nostrils, and open-mouthed smile. As with the full-bodied 🐒 Monkey, often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Available as an Apple Animoji. Vendors implement the same or similar monkey face in their Three Wise Monkeys emojis: 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey, 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey, and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey. Facebook’s monkey previously resembled 🐻 Bear Face. Monkey Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A monkey, a small primate with long limbs and tail for climbing trees. Generally depicted as a cartoon-styled, brown monkey with a cheeky facial expression, shown in full profile facing left, sitting on its hind legs with a long, curled tail and round ears. As with 🐵 Monkey Face, often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. WhatsApp’s monkey is facing right, Facebook’s has shaggy hair. Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A gorilla, the powerful, black-haired great ape. Variously depicted in full profile on all fours facing left or as a friendly, cartoon-styled gorilla face looking straight ahead. Apple, WhatsApp, Facebook, and Microsoft’s designs feature a full gorilla, as a silverback, with strong shoulders and reddish forehead. Google, Samsung, and Twitter’s designs feature a black and gray gorilla face with a neutral expression and prominent forehead and jaw. Facebook’s design previously featured only a gorilla face. Gorilla was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

An orangutan, the orange-haired ape with long arms. Depicted facing forward, with a long broad face and sitting with its legs bent. Often shown scratching its head. Skin color varies across platforms, ranging from light to dark. Google’s orangutan has purplish skin, Twitter's is smiling. Orangutan was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

What a good doggo! A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a dog, looking straight ahead. Depicted as the face of a dog of various breeds, generally light-brown and white, with pointed or floppy ears and its tongue hanging out. May be used with a more playful tone than the full-bodied 🐕 Dog, though their applications generally overlap. See also 🐩 Poodle. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Available as an Apple Animoji. Many vendors implement the same or similar dog as their full-bodied 🐕 Dog, such as Google and Facebook, which feature a Shiba Inu. Apple, Microsoft, and WhatsApp’s dogs have a white face with brown, floppy ears and a brown patch over one eye. Included in the earliest Japanese emoji sets from Softbank, Docomo, and au by KDDI. Dog Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dog, a faithful, beloved pet canine. Depicted as a light-brown dog, of various breeds, in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long, curled tail held upright and pointed or floppy ears. Google and Facebook’s dogs resemble a reddish-brown Shiba Inu, a popular Japanese breed featured in the Doge meme. See also 🐩 Poodle and 🐶 Dog Face, whose applications may overlap. Some vendors implement the same or a similar dog in their 🦮 Guide Dog and 🐕‍🦺 Service Dog. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac.

Google and Facebook previously featured puppies with collars, Apple’s dog previously resembled an Akita Inu, another popular Japanese breed. Dog was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A guide (or Seeing Eye) dog, trained to help lead a person who is blind or visually impaired. Generally depicted as a yellowish-brown Labrador Retriever on all fours facing left, equipped with a harness and handle. Many platforms additionally include a collar. Not to be confused with 🐕‍🦺 Service Dog, though their popular applications may overlap. Twitter implements the same dog as its 🐕 Dog. Samsung and Twitter’s guide dogs have green harnesses. Guide Dog was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A service animal displayed with a safety vest and lead. Differs from the guide dog as this animal is intended for detection of seizures or other “hidden disabilities”, according to the proposal from Apple. The Service Dog emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🐕 Dog, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦺 Safety Vest. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Service Dog was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A poodle, a popular dog breed with curly hair, often groomed in an ornamental pattern. Generally depicted as a grayish-white poodle in full profile on all fours facing left, with a shaved torso, legs, and face with fuller, pom-pom-like hair on its head, ears, chest, feet, and tip of tail (as the Continental Clip). Like 🐕 Dog, may be used to represent a variety of dog breeds (often fluffy or long-haired). See also 🐶 Dog Face. With an upturned snout, Google’s poodle bears an endearingly haughty expression. Google, Samsung, and Facebook’s design previously featured pink poodles. Poodle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The face of a wolf, a howling canine that hunts in packs. Generally depicted as a cartoon-styled face of a gray wolf with pointed ears, white cheeks and muzzle, and black nose. Its expression is variously neutral, friendly, or slightly menacing, as in Google and Samsung’s designs. Apple’s design features the head of gray wolf, facing left. Occasionally used to represent metaphorical senses of wolf, e.g., lone wolf, wolf pack. Apple and SoftBank’s designs previously resembled a reddish-brown canine, resembling a dog or fox. Wolf was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Wolf Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled faced of a fox, the cunning canine, looking straight ahead. Depicted as an orange fox  face with a black nose, pointed ears, and shaggy, white cheeks. Often used with an affectionate or playful tone (e.g., slang, foxy). Does not have a full-bodied fox emoji counterpart. Available as an Apple Animoji. Fox was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Fox Face” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A raccoon, a nocturnal mammal with a mask around its eyes. Generally depicted as a friendly, cartoon-styled, gray raccoon face looking straight ahead, with black-and-white markings around its eyes and pointed ears and cheeks. Apple and WhatsApp’s designs feature a raccoon in full profile on all fours facing left with a striped, bushy tail. Raccoon was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

Meow! A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a cat, looking straight ahead. Generally depicted as a yellowish-orange cat face with pointed ears and whiskers. May be used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐈 Cat, though their applications generally overlap. Available as an Apple Animoji. Vendors implement the same or similar cat in their 🐈 Cat as well as in their cat-faced variants of smileys: Google’s cat face was previously orange, Samsung’s gray, and Facebook’s once gray and white. Included in the earliest Japanese emoji sets from Softbank, Docomo, and au by KDDI. Cat Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A domestic cat, beloved as a pet. Generally depicted as a light-orange cat with stripes, as a tabby, in full profile on all fours facing left, with its long tell held upright. See also 🐱 Cat Face. Google’s cat is cartoon-styled, shown sitting on its hind legs with a friendly expression and whiskers. Facebook’s cat is a gray tabby, though previously was orange. Microsoft and Samsung’s cats were previously gray, Twitter’s brown. Cat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Black Cat emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🐈 Cat, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ⬛ Black Large Square. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Black Cat was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a lion—the large cat and king of the jungle—looking straight ahead. Depicted as a golden-yellow lion face with a light- or dark-brown mane, white muzzle, and neutral expression. Often used with an affectionate tone. Does not have a full-bodied lion emoji counterpart. A lion is represented as ♌ Leo in the Western zodiac. Available as an Apple Animoji. Apple's lion previously featured a timid-looking expression. Lion was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Lion Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a tiger looking straight ahead. Generally depicted in yellowish-orange with black stripes on its forehead and cheeks, a white muzzle, and neutral expression. Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐅 Tiger. Available as an Apple Animoji. Tiger Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A tiger, a large cat with an orange coat and black stripes. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long tail, its distinctive stripes, and, on some platforms, white patches. See also 🐯 Tiger Face. Not to be confused with 🐆 Leopard. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Google’s design is noticeably more cartoon-styled, as Facebook’s previously was. Microsoft’s design previously featured a yellow, forward-facing tiger, as if on the prowl. Tiger was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A leopard, a large cat with a yellowish-brown coat and black-and-gold spots. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long tail and its distinctive pattern. Sometimes used to represent jaguars, panthers, cheetahs, and related cats. May also be used to indicate leopard prints in fashion. Not to be confused with 🐅 Tiger. Google’s design is noticeably more cartoon-styled. Microsoft’s design was previously solid yellowish-brown in color, resembling a cougar or mountain lion. Leopard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The face of a horse, generally facing left. Depicted as a light or reddish-brown horse with a dark brown or black mane, and, on many platforms, a light-colored muzzle. Not to be confused with the full-bodied 🐎 Horse or 🏇 Horse Racing, though their applications may overlap. Some vendors implement a similar design in 🦄 Unicorn Face and 🦓 Zebra. WhatsApp’s horse is facing left, as Facebook’s previously was. Microsoft’s horse was previously looking straight ahead, as was Samsung’s, shown with a goofy, full-toothed grin. Softbank previously featured a full-bodied horse. Horse Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A horse, a hoofed mammal used for riding and racing. Depicted as a brown horse in full profile galloping to the left, with a dark, flowing mane and tail. May be used to represent various types of horses and their metaphorical senses (e.g., mustang, stallion). One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Not to be confused with 🐴 Horse Face, 🎠 Carousel Horse, and 🏇 Horse Racing, which features a jockey on its back. Apple’s horse is wearing a green saddle blanket, Facebook’s a blue blanket with saddle. SoftBank’s design previously featured a racing horse with a jockey. Horse was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The face of a unicorn, a mythical creature in the form of a white horse with a single, long horn on its forehead. Generally depicted as a white horse head facing left with a pink or purple mane and a yellow or rainbow-colored horn. In addition to the mythical unicorn, may be used to convey whimsy, fantasy, uniqueness, specialness, peace, and love. Often used for various content related to the LGBTQ community, thanks in part to its rainbow colors on many platforms. Also often used in association with “unicorn” startups. Sometimes used as a rainbow or holographic accent color. Vendors implement the emoji with the same or similar design as 🐴 Horse Face, but with colorful hair and a horn. Available as an Apple Animoji. WhatsApp’s unicorn is facing right. Google’s unicorn previously had a brown mane, Samsung’s a pink mane. Twitter’s unicorn was previously purple-colored with a blue mane. Unicorn was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Unicorn Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A zebra, a horse-like mammal with black-and-white stripes. Variously depicted in full profile on all fours facing left or as a zebra head facing left with a short mane. Not to be confused with 🐎 Horse. Some vendors implement a similar face as their 🐴 Horse Face. Apple, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s designs feature the full animal; Google, Microsoft, and Samsung’s designs feature a head with a short mane and black muzzle. Facebook’s design previously featured only a zebra head. Zebra was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Zebra Face” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A deer, a fleet-footed, hoofed mammal whose males (bucks, stags) generally have antlers. Variously depicted as a light-brown deer in full profile on all fours facing left or as a deer face looking straight head; both depictions feature large, branched antlers. May be used to represent elk, moose, antelope, or reindeer, especially in connection with Christmas. Apple, Microsoft, WhatsApp, and Facebook's designs feature a deer in full profile; Google, Samsung, and Twitter's designs feature a deer face. Google’s deer has a red nose, as Rudolph the Red-nosed Reindeer. Apple and WhatsApp’s deers are white-tailed. Deer was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
Bison was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a cow looking straight ahead. Variously depicted as a white, brown, or multicolored cow face with a neutral expression, short horns, and a pink or brown muzzle. Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐄 Cow. Facebook’s design once featured a more lifelike, brown cow face. Cow Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An ox, a bovine used as a draft animal. Depicted in brown in full profile on all fours facing left, with a tail and short horns. Often used to represent a bull. Occasionally paired with 💩 Pile of Poo to stand in for slang terms. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Often used to represent ♉ Taurus (the Bull) in the Western zodiac. Not to be confused with 🐃 Water Buffalo. Facebook’s ox was previously gray. Ox was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A water buffalo, a bovine used to plough rice fields in parts of Asia. Depicted in gray or black in full profile on all fours facing left, with a tail and broad horns curled up at the tips. Often used to represent a bull. Not to be confused with 🐂 Ox, though their applications may overlap. Microsoft’s design was previously brown. Water Buffalo was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A cow, a bovine farmed for its meat or milk. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left with a black-and-white patched coat (as a Holstein Friesian) and, on many platforms, a pink udder and horns. May be used to represent the animal, its food products, or black-and-white coloring. See also 🐮 Cow Face. Microsoft's cow was previously brown, as was Facebook's, which had a bell around its neck. Cow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a pig looking straight ahead. Depicted as a pink face with a neutral expression, pointed or floppy ears, and distinctive pig nose. Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐖 Pig. Available as an Apple Animoji. Apple’s face bears a slight grin and previously featured floppy ears. Pig Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A pig, a plump animal farmed for its meat, such as bacon. Depicted in light pink in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long snout and short, curly tail. May be used to represent the animal, its food products, or various metaphorical senses of pig. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac; 2019 is the Year of the Pig. See also 🐷 Pig Face, 🐽 Pig Nose, and 🐗 Boar. WhatsApp’s design previously featured a wide grin. Pig was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A boar, a hairy, wild pig with tusks. Generally depicted as the face of a brown boar, either facing left or looking straight ahead, with prominent tusks projecting from its lower jaw. Microsoft, Twitter, and Facebook’s design feature a friendly, cartoon-styled face with a snout. WhatsApp’s design displays the animal in full, as Google, Microsoft, and Samsung previously did. Not to be confused with 🐖 Pig or 🐷 Pig Face, though their applications may overlap. Available as an Apple Animoji. Boar was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The snout of a pig. Depicted as a pink oval or slightly pear-shaped nose with two black nostrils. See also 🐖 Pig and 🐷 Pig Face. Previously displayed as a cute pig character on Google Gmail. Pig Nose was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A ram, a male sheep with large, spiraling horns. Generally depicted in full profile on all fours facing left with a thick, white fleece and light-brown horns. Occasionally used to represent antelopes and related animals. Not to be confused with 🐑 Ewe, though their applications may overlap. Often considered (in lieu of 🐐 Goat) one of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Also often used to represent ♈ Aries (the Ram) in the Western zodiac. WhatsApp and Facebook’s designs resemble a bighorn sheep, as did Apple’s once did. Ram was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A ewe, or female sheep raised for its wool, meat, and milk and without the spiraling horns of a ram. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left with a thick, white fleece and black, gray, or white skin. Not to be confused with 🐏 Ram, though their applications may overlap. Often considered (in lieu of 🐐 Goat) one of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Apple and Google’s designs previously depicted a ram. Samsung and Facebook’s designs previously featured only a ewe face. Ewe was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Sheep” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A goat, a sturdy, hoofed animal raised for its meat and milk. Depicted as a light brown, white, or multicored goat in full profile on all fours facing left, a scraggly beard, upright tail, and brown or yellow horns curving back. Frequently used as a visual shorthand for the slang expression GOAT, or the Great of All Time, often said of athletes and in particular the late Kobe Bryant. Often considered one of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Also often used to represent ♑ Capricorn in the Western zodiac. Apple, Google, and Samsung’s goats were previously white, as a Saanen goat. Facebook’s design previously featured only a goat face. Goat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dromedary camel, a long-necked mammal with one large hump on its back. Depicted in light or yellowish brown in full profile on all fours facing left. Not to be confused with 🐫 Two-Hump Camel (Bactrian), though their applications generally overlap. May be used in association with deserts, the Middle East, and Wednesday (Hump Day). Samsung’s design features a camel with a shaggy head of hair and slight smile. Google’s design previously featured a blanket on its back, as for transport. Camel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dromedary Camel” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A Bactrian camel, a long-necked mammal with two large humps on its back. Depicted in light or yellowish brown, sometimes with a shaggy mane and humps, in full profile on all fours facing left. Not to be confused with 🐪 Camel (dromedary), though their applications generally overlap. May be used in association with deserts, the Middle East and Central Asia, and Wednesday (Hump Day). Samsung’s design features a camel with a shaggy head of hair and slight smile. Google’s design previously featured a blanket on its back, as for transport. Two-Hump Camel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bactrian Camel” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A llama, a long-necked, camel-like animal, native to South America and used for transport and wool. Depicted as a shaggy white, light-brown, or multicolored llama in full profile on all fours facing left. May be used to represent an alpaca or related animals. Llama was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A giraffe, the tallest animal on Earth, with spots and a long neck. Generally depicted in yellow or tan in full profile on all fours facing left, with distinctive brown spots and small, horn-like structures. Microsoft and Samsung’s designs feature a giraffe face looking straight ahead. Facebook’s design previously featured only a giraffe face. Giraffe was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Giraffe Face” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

An elephant, the largest land animal on Earth, with a long trunk and, often, tusks. Generally depicted in gray in full profile on all fours facing left, with tusks and prominent ears, as an African (vs. Asian) elephant. Google and Facebook’s elephants were previously blue in color. Samsung’s design previously featured a cartoon-styled elephant with a red blanket on its back and blowing a red heart from its trunk. Elephant was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Mammoth was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A rhinoceros, a large mammal with one or two massive horns on its nose. Generally shown in light gray with two horns, depicted in full profile on all fours or as a rhinoceros head looking left. Resembles the white or black rhinoceros. Apple, Microsoft, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s designs feature the full animal; Google, Samsung, and Twitter’s designs feature only a rhinoceros head. Facebook’s design previously featured only a rhinoceros head. Rhinoceros was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A hippopotamus, a squat water mammal with huge jaws. Generally depicted in pinkish gray in full profile on all fours facing left. Google’s design features a purple, cartoon-styled hippopotamus face. Facebook’s hippopotamus is opening massive jaws, revealing tusks. Hippopotamus was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a mouse, looking straight ahead. Generally depicted as a gray or white mouse face with large, round ears, a pink, pointed nose, and whiskers. Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐁 Mouse. Not to be confused with 🐹 Hamster Face. Google’s mouse is squinting with a buck tooth, which Facebook’s mouse also has. Microsoft’s design was previously brown. Mouse Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Eek! A mouse, a small rodent with large ears and a long tail. Generally depicted in white in full profile on all fours facing left, with pink ears, feet, and tail, often with reddish eyes. See also 🐭 Mouse Face. Not to be confused with 🐀 Rat—or 🖱️ Computer Mouse. Google’s design is noticeably more cartoon-styled, standing on its hind legs and facing forward with a buck tooth. Facebook’s mouse is sitting on its hind legs. Microsoft’s mouse was previously brown. Mouse was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A rat, a large rodent with a long tail, known to frequent big cities. Depicted in gray in full profile on all fours facing left, with pink ears, feet, and tail. May be use for various metaphorical senses of rat. Not to be confused with 🐁 Mouse, which has white hair. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Google’s design is noticeably more cartoon-styled, standing on its hind legs and facing forward with a buck tooth. Rat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a hamster—a small rodent often kept as a pet—looking straight ahead. Generally depicted as a brown-and-white faced hamster with whiskers, a pink nose, puffy cheeks, and large, round, pink ears, sometimes with a buck tooth. Often used with an affectionate tone. May be used to represent a gerbil, guinea pig, chinchilla, or related animals. Does not have a full-bodied hamster emoji counterpart. Not to be confused with 🐭 Mouse Face. Microsoft’s hamster was previously gray. Hamster was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Hamster Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a rabbit, looking straight ahead. Generally depicted as a gray and/or white rabbit face with upright ears and pink ears and nose, often with whiskers and a buck tooth. Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐇 rabbit. Also often used to represent the Easter Bunny. Available as an Apple Animoji. Microsoft’s rabbit face was previously pink-colored with one ear flopping down. Facebook’s rabbit face was previously gray-colored with both ears flopping down. Rabbit Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A rabbit, a hoppy mammal with long ears. Depicted as a white, gray, or brown rabbit in full profile facing left with pink ears and a short tail, sitting on its long, hind legs or on all fours. May be used in association with spring, Easter, magic, bunny ears, or various rabbit-based characters or expressions (e.g., going down the rabbit hole). See also 🐰 Rabbit Face. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Apple’s rabbit has red eyes, WhatsApp’s whiskers. Microsoft’s rabbit was previously brown, Facebook’s white. Rabbit was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A chipmunk, a squirrel-like rodent with puffy cheeks. Depicted as a reddish-brown chipmunk in full profile facing left, sitting on its hind legs with a bushy tail and striped face and body. Generally holding an acorn or other nut in its forelimbs. Often used with an affectionate tone. May be used to represent a squirrel or related animals. Google’s chipmunk is looking forward, squinting with a buck tooth. Microsoft’s previous black-and-white design could be mistaken for a skunk. Chipmunk was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Beaver was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A hedgehog, a small, spiny mammal sometimes kept as a pat. Generally depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a round, brown body covered with spines and a light-brown face and underside. Sometimes used to represent a porcupine or echidna. Google and Twitter’s designs show a hedgehog facing forward. Apple and WhatsApp’s design suggest a slight smile. Facebook’s design previously featured a hedgehog on its back, rolled up in a ball. Hedgehog was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A bat, the flying mammal of the night. Variously depicted as a brown, black, or gray bat, with wings outspread and pointy ears, facing forward or left. Often used in association with Halloween, vampires, and Batman. Google’s bat is purplish in color, bearing two fangs. Samsung’s bat was previously brown, Facebook’s gray. Bat was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of bear, looking straight ahead. Depicted as a brown bear with round ears and a tan muzzle. Resembles a teddy bear. Often used with an affectionate tone. Does not have a full-bodied bear emoji counterpart. Available as an Apple Animoji. Samsung’s bear was previously golden brown. Bear was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bear Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Polar Bear emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🐻 Bear, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ❄️ Snowflake. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Polar Bear was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a koala—a bear-like marsupial known for eating eucalyptus and sleeping—looking straight ahead. Depicted as a gray face with round, fluffy ears and a large, black nose. Often used with an affectionate tone and in association with Australia, where the animal is found. Available as an Apple Animoji. Google’s koala was previously climbing a tree. Softbank’s koala previously resembled 🐻 Bear Face. Koala was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a panda—a bear-like mammal known for eating bamboo—looking straight ahead. Depicted as a white panda face with black ears and black circles around its eyes. Often used with an affectionate tone and in association with China, where the animal is found. Sometimes used to represent a red panda. Does not have a full-bodied panda emoji counterpart. Available as an Apple Animoji. Google and Facebook’s pandas are shown smiling with an open mouth and tongue. Panda was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Panda Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sloth, the slow-moving, tree-dwelling mammal. Depicted as a light-brown sloth with a wide, whitish, masked face hanging from a tree branch, facing left or right. Generally shown as a three-toed sloth. Sloth was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

An otter, the playful water mammal in the weasel family. Depicted as a light-brown otter on its back, with its forepaws held together and whiskered face to the left, generally with its long tail curled up. Apple’s otter is in water, holding a stone, as is Microsoft’s. Otter was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A skunk, a bushy-tailed mammal that sprays a foul odor when threatened. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with black hair and its distinctive white stripe running from its head down to a curled-up tail. Google’s skunk bears a humorously haughty air. Skunk was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A kangaroo, a marsupial with a large tail and legs. Depicted in yellowish-brown in full profile facing left with large, pointed ears, shown either resting on its hind legs and tail or jumping. Commonly used in connection with Australia, where the animal is found. Kangaroo was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A badger, a stocky mammal in the weasel family with a long, pointed head. Generally depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a gray coat, black-and-white-striped face, and short tail. Google’s design features a friendly, cartoon-styled black-and-white badger face. Facebook’s badger is sitting on its hind legs. Badger was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A pair of paw prints, as left by a pet 🐈 cat or 🐕 dog. Generally depicted as two, staggered, dark-colored paw prints, each showing four toes and a pad. Commonly used for various content concerning pet cats and dogs. Occasionally applied to other quadruped mammals. See also 👣 Footprints. Google and Twitter’s prints are red and Microsoft’s orange, as if a pet walked through paint. Apple and Facebook’s prints were previously red, Google’s blue, and Microsoft’s gray. Facebook's design originally displayed human footprints. Paw Prints was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A turkey, a gobbling bird traditionally eaten at Thanksgiving or Christmas. Depicted in full profile facing left, standing on its legs with a dark-brown body, a white-fringed plume, pink or blue head, and its distinctive red snood and wattle. May be consumed in the form of 🍗 Poultry Leg. Turkey was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A chicken, a bird used for its meat and eggs. Generally depicted as the white head of a chicken (hen or rooster) looking left, with a yellow beak, red comb on its head, and red wattle on its neck. May be consumed in the form of 🍗 Poultry Leg. Not to be confused with the full-bodied 🐓 Rooster, though their applications overlap. Also may be used for metaphorical senses of chicken (e.g., “coward”). See also 🐣 Hatching Chick, 🐤 Baby Chick, and 🐥 Front-Facing Baby Chick. Available as an Apple Animoji. Google’s design features a full chicken, Twitter’s chicken head is looking straight ahead. Microsoft’s chicken was previously yellow, Samsung’s facing forward; Facebook’s design once featured a full, brown bird. Chicken was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A rooster (cock), a male chicken known for its cock-a-doodle-do. Depicted as a white or multicolored rooster standing on its legs in full profile facing left, with a red comb on its head and red wattle on its neck. Not to be confused with 🐔 Chicken, though their applications overlap. See also 🐣 Hatching Chick, 🐤 Baby Chick, and 🐥 Front-Facing Baby Chick. Occasionally used as sexual slang. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Google’s rooster is brown with a green tail, Facebook’s brown with a blue tail. Google’s rooster was previously white, Microsoft’s yellow, Samsung’s looking straight ahead. Rooster was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A baby chicken (chick), hatching from an egg and seeing the world for the first time. Depicted as a yellow chick with an orange beak facing forward in the cracked, bottom half of a white egg, generally shown flapping its wings with a cute facial expression. Often used with an affectionate tone. May be used to represent various types of baby birds. May also be used to represent chicken foods (e.g., poultry, eggs), spring, Easter, or slang senses of chick. Not to be confused with 🐤 Baby Chick or 🐥Front-Facing Baby Chick (out of its egg), though their applications overlap. See also 🐔 Chicken and 🐓 Rooster. Twitter and Facebook's designs do not include wings. Google's design previously featured motion lines around the chick's wings, indicating flapping. Facebook's design previously showed part of the egg atop the chick's head. Hatching Chick was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A yellow baby chicken (chick). Variously depicted as a chick in full profile, standing on its legs, or as a chick head. Both designs show the bird facing left, with an orange beak and feet. Often used with an affectionate tone. May be used to represent various types of baby birds. May also be used to represent chicken foods (e.g., poultry, eggs), spring, Easter, or slang senses of chick. Not to be confused with 🐣 Hatching Chick or 🐥Front-Facing Baby Chick, though their applications overlap. See also 🐔 Chicken and 🐓 Rooster. Apple, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s designs feature a chick head; other major platforms display a full-bodied chick. Baby Chick was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A baby chicken (chick), shown as if flapping its wings. Depicted as a yellow chick with an orange beak in full profile standing on its legs, generally with its wings raised. Often used with an affectionate tone. May be used to represent various types of baby birds. May also be used to represent chicken foods (e.g., poultry, eggs), spring, Easter, or slang senses of chick. Not to be confused with 🐤 Baby Chick or 🐣 Hatching Chick (still in its egg), though their applications overlap. See also 🐔 Chicken and 🐓 Rooster. Facebook's design previously featured only a chick head facing forward. Front-Facing Baby Chick was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A generic bird. Variously depicted as a blue or red bird, as a bluebird or cardinal, shown standing in full profile, or as a bird head. Both designs show the bird facing left. May be used for a variety of wild and pet birds as well as for metaphorical senses of bird (e.g., birdie in golf). Apple and WhatsApp’s designs feature a grayish bird head. Google, Samsung, and Facebook’s designs suggest a bluebird, Microsoft and Twitter’s a cardinal. Google’s bird previously resembled a canary, Samsung’s was previously green, and Microsoft and Twitter’s birds were once blue. Bird was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A penguin, a flightless bird adapted to water and ice. Variously depicted as a full, black-bodied penguin with a white belly and orange bill or as a penguin head. Often used with an affectionate or playful tone or in association with the cold. Occasionally used to represent a puffin. Apple and WhatsApp’s designs feature a penguin head, with Apple’s bearing a yellow patch on its head, as an emperor penguin. Other major platforms feature a penguin standing in full profile, facing forward or left. Penguin was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dove carrying an olive branch, a symbol of peace in Western and Judeo-Christian culture. Depicted as a white bird in full profile facing left, flying as it holds a green sprig in its beak. Commonly used to represent such sentiments as peace, love, hope, and reconciliation. Microsoft’s dove was previously flying right, without an olive branch. Dove was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Dove of Peace” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A bald eagle, the majestic bird of prey with brown feathers and distinctive white head. Generally depicted facing left, with its wings outspread and talons out, as if swooping down to seize prey. Commonly associated with the United States, whose national emblem is the bald eagle. May be used for other eagles and birds of prey (e.g., hawks) more generally. Google’s eagle has its wings tucked in, as if perched on a branch. Twitter’s design shows only the bust of an eagle. Apple’s 📰 Newspaper features its eagle on its masthead. Eagle was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

Quack! A duck, a waterbird with webbed feet. Depicted as a male (drake) mallard in full profile facing left, standing on its legs with gray and brown feathers, a yellow bill, and its distinctive green head. May be consumed in the form of a 🍗 Poultry Leg. Occasionally used as a substitute for the F-word, due to rhyming and Apple's iPhone autocorrect. Samsung’s design previously featured a yellow rubber ducky. Duck was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A swan, a waterbird with white feathers and a long neck. Depicted in full profile facing left, with a curving neck, orange bill, black eye marking, and wings and legs tucked in, as if gliding in water. May be used to represent a goose or, metaphorically, love, grace, and beauty. Swan was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

An owl, the hooting, large-eyed bird of the night. Depicted as a reddish-brown owl, as a great horned owl, facing forward, Shown with large, round, gold-rimmed eyes, feet curled on or as if on a branch, wings tucked in, and its distinctive, horn-like tufts of feathers. May be used to represent wisdom. Popularly used in connection with the hip-hop artist Drake. Apple and Microsoft’s owls are on a branch. Microsoft’s owl previously resembled a barn owl, Samsung’s was purple. Owl was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
Dodo was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Feather was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A flamingo, a waterbird with pink feathers and long neck and legs. Depicted as a flamingo in full profile facing left, standing on one leg, usually with a long, black beak. May be used to represent summer fun or as a pink accent color. Flamingo was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A peacock, the male bird that displays a large, fan-like, iridescent tale. Depicted facing forward standing on its legs, with a blue body and green tail feathers outspread. Sometimes used to suggest something is beautiful or proud. Also sometimes used to accent a peacock-like color or pattern. Peacock was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A parrot, a brightly colored tropical bird known for its ability to mimic speech. Depicted in full profile facing left standing on its legs. Variously resembles a green lovebird (with red- and-yellow-tipped wings) or a scarlet macaw (with blue-and-yellow-striped wings). May be used to represent various pet parrots and other pet birds. Facebook’s parrot is orange with blue-tipped wings. Google's parrot is perched on a branch. Parrot was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The face of a frog, the hopping amphibian. Generally depicted as a friendly, cartoon-styled, light-green frog looking straight ahead, with large eyes, slightly open mouth, and nostrils. Popularly paired with ☕️ Hot Beverage to represent the But That’s None of My Business meme (used for gossip or sarcasm) or Pepe the Frog (associated with trolling and the alt-right). Facebook’s design previously resembled Kermit the Frog. Frog was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Frog Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A crocodile, a stealthy reptile with massive jaws. Generally depicted as a light-green crocodile on all fours, with its long tail curving down to its toothed jaws, facing left. May resemble and be used for an alligator. Facebook's crocodile is opening its jaws. Samsung’s design previously resembled a kind of cartoon dinosaur. Crocodile was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A turtle, a slow-moving reptile with a shell. Depicted as a light-green turtle in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long neck and green, textured shell. May be used to represent a tortoise and various senses of slow. WhatsApp’s turtle has light-brown skin, Microsoft and Facebook’s a yellow-rimmed shell. Turtle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A lizard, a scaly reptile with a long tail. Depicted as a light-green lizard on all fours from above, generally looking left with large eyes, a lightly textured or colored back, and toes outspread, as a gecko. May be used for a variety of wild and pet lizards. Google’s lizard was previously brown. Lizard was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A snake, a slithering reptile without limbs. Generally depicted as a yellowish-green snake facing left, with a long, coiled body and flicking a red, forked tongue. May be used for various metaphorical senses of snake. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. May also be used in association with ⛎ Ophiuchus, the Serpent-Bearer, sometimes considered a 13th sign of the Western zodiac. Samsung’s snake was previously facing forward. Snake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The face of a dragon, a mythical creature resembling a giant reptile found in the folklore of many cultures. Depicted as a green, Chinese-styled dragon looking straight ahead or facing left. Often shown with huge nostrils, baring large teeth and a red tongue, with antler-like structures on its head, whisker-like tendrils by its nostrils, and a green or yellow mane. See also 🐉 Dragon. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Commonly used on Chinese New Year and St. George's Day. Also used for various medieval and fantasy content. Available as an Apple Animoji. Microsoft's dragon face was previously red and looking straight ahead. Samsung's dragon face previously resembled a red, friendly, cartoon-styled imp with horns. Dragon Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dragon, a mythical creature resembling a giant reptile found in the folklore of many cultures. Depicted as a green, Chinese-styled dragon in full profile facing left. Generally shown with a curling, snake-like body, clawed feet, yellowish scales on its back, horn-like structures on its head, and whisker-like tendrils by its nostrils. See also 🐲 Dragon Face. One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Commonly used on Chinese New Year and St. George's Day. Also used for various medieval and fantasy content. Apple's dragon is holding a glowing blue orb, as a 🔮 Crystal Ball. Facebook's dragon is bluish in color. Microsoft's dragon was previously red, Samsung's a more cartoon-styled, baby dragon holding a blue orb. Dragon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sauropod, a massive, plant-eating dinosaur with a long neck and tail. Depicted as a blue, gray, or green sauropod, as a brachiosaurus, apatosaurus/brontosaurus, or diplodocus. Shown in full profile on all fours facing left. May be used to represent various dinosaurs. See also 🦖 T-Rex. Apple, Google and Samsung's sauropods resemble a brachiosaurus. Samsung’s sauropod was previously green, Facebook’s previously displayed only a green head. Sauropod was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A Tyrannosaurus rex, a massive, meat-eating dinosaur with huge jaws, tiny arms, and a long tail. Depicted as a green or brown tyrannosaur standing on its hind lefts facing left, often with a textured back, sharp teeth, and clawed toes. May be used to represent various dinosaurs, including raptors. See also 🦕 Sauropod. Google’s T-Rex resembles a velociraptor. Samsung’s T-Rex was previously red, Facebook’s only a green head with open jaws. T-Rex was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A friendly, cartoon-styled whale, shown spouting water from its blowhole. Generally depicted as a light-blue whale in full profile facing left, with a round body and white underside, its tail held upright. Often used with an affectionate tone. Not to be confused with the more lifelike 🐋 Whale, though their applications may overlap. WhatsApp’s whale is gray, as Microsoft and Facebook’s whales previously were. Twitter’s whale was previously purple. Spouting Whale was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A whale, the massive marine mammal. Generally depicted as a light-blue whale in full profile facing left, with its tail curving down towards is huge mouth. Shown with a white, textured underside, as a humpback or blue whale. Not to be confused with the more cartoon-styled 🐳 Spouting Whale, though their applications may overlap. Apple and Microsoft’s whales have slightly open mouths, revealing baleen. Whale was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dolphin, a sleek marine mammal known to be social and intelligent. Generally depicted as a light-blue dolphin with a white belly in full profile facing left, its short snout curving down to a prominent dorsal fin and tail, as a bottlenose dolphin leaping in the air. May be used for various content concerning swimming, oceans, beaches, and summer fun. Not be confused with 🦈 Shark. WhatsApp and Facebook’s dolphins are gray, as Microsoft and Samsung’s previously were. Dolphin was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Seal was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A common fish, as swims in the water. Depicted as a generic, light-blue fish, often with a white underside, in full profile facing left, with fins and prominent gill cover. May be used to represent a variety of other fish (freshwater or saltwater), fishing, metaphorical senses of fish, and fish as food, as consumed in the form of 🍣 Sushi. May be used to represent ♓ Pisces, the Fish, in the Western zodiac. Not to be confused with 🐠 Tropical Fish or 🐡 Blowfish, though their applications may overlap. Vendors implement a similar design to the fish caught on the 🎣 Fishing Pole. Microsoft’s fish was previously yellow. Fish was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A tropical fish, as swims in the warm waters of a coral reef or is kept as a pet in an aquarium. Depicted as a brightly colored fish in full profile facing left, with slender fins. Often shown as a blue-and-yellow fish with stripes, as an angelfish. May be used to represent a variety of fish (saltwater or freshwater), fishing, metaphorical senses of fish, and fish as food, as consumed in the form of 🍣 Sushi. Not to be confused with 🐟 Fish or 🐡 Blowfish, though their applications may overlap. See also 🎣 Fishing Pole. Microsoft’s fish is orange with white stripes. Google and Facebook’s fish previously resembled a goldfish. Microsoft’s was previously yellow and blue, Samsung’s black and white. Tropical Fish was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A blowfish (puffer), which puffs up and becomes spiky when alarmed. Depicted as an orange or brown blowfish in full profile facing left, with small fins, a white underside, and a round, spiky body, as if inflated. Called fugu in Japan, where it’s consumed as a delicacy. May be to represent a variety of fish (saltwater or freshwater), fishing, metaphorical senses of fish, and fish as food, as consumed in the form of 🍣 Sushi. Not to be confused with 🐟 Fish or 🐠 Tropical Fish, though their applications may overlap. See also 🎣 Fishing Pole. Google’s blowfish was previously blue, Microsoft’s yellow, and Facebook’s white. Blowfish was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A shark, a large, stealthy fish with many teeth. Generally depicted as a gray shark in full profile facing left, as a tiger, bull, or great white shark hunting in the water. Shown with a white underside and three gills, its pointed nose and teeth-lined mouth curving down to a sharp dorsal fin and long, pointed tail. Not to be confused with 🐬 Dolphin. Shark was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

An octopus, a sea animal with eight legs, known to change color and release ink. Generally depicted as a pink or orange octopus facing forward, with a large, round head, prominent eyes, and its tentacle-like arms raised at its sides. Platforms vary in the number of arms shown, ranging from four to the full eight, with several designs featuring suckers on them. Not to be confused with 🦑 Squid, though their applications may overlap. Twitter’s octopus is purple. Apple’s has a friendly, cartoon-styled appearance.
