Google and Samsung’s octopuses previously looked surprised, while Microsoft's suggested an 👾 Alien Monster. Octopus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A seashell, as found at the beach. Generally depicted as an empty, spiraling, white seashell, as grown by a sea snail or home to a hermit crab. Positioned at various angles across platforms. Often used for various content concerning beaches, ocean and ocean life, and summer fun. Microsoft’s shell is peach-colored. Apple’s design previously resembled a clam shell, Microsoft’s a snail shell. Google’s was previously blue. Spiral Shell was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A snail, a slow-moving, snail-like mollusk in a spiraling shell. Generally depicted as a brown snail in full profile facing left or right, with a brown, textured shell and tentacle-like eyes. May be used to represent a slug and various senses of slow. Twitter’s snail has a purple body and yellow shell. Microsoft’s snail previously had a green body. Snail was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A butterfly, a beautiful winged insect whose larva is a caterpillar. Depicted with its wings outspread, as a blue-and-black morpho butterfly or orange-and-black monarch butterfly. May be used to represent a moth and ideas of beauty and happiness. Samsung’s butterfly previously resembled a monarch. Butterfly was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A bug, or insect, generally depicted as a caterpillar, which becomes a 🦋 Butterfly. Shown in full profile facing left, inching up on the back of its green, segmented, and textured body. Often featuring black stripes or yellow dots and tentacles on its head. May be used to represent various insects, worms, and related animals. May also be used for metaphorical senses of bug. Twitter’s bug is purple. Apple’s bug is hairy with a red head and legs and black stripes on its body. Microsoft’s bug also has a red head, Facebook’s is yellowish-orange. Google and Microsoft’s bugs previously resembled an orange centipede or millipede, and Samsung’s had a cartoon-styled face with a purple nose. Bug was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An ant, a small, industrious insect that lives in a colony. Depicted as a black or red ant in full profile on its six legs facing left, with a prominent abdomen and antennae. May be used to represent various insects or other bugs. Microsoft and Facebook’s ants are red. Google’s ant was previously blue, Facebook’s black. Ant was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A honey bee, a busy, flying insect that lives in a hive and makes honey. Depicted as a black-and-yellow bee with clear or white wings and a stinger. Variously facing left in full profile or shown from above. May be used to represent various types of bees (e.g., bumblebee) and wasps (e.g., hornets, yellow jackets). May also be used to accent black-and-yellow colors or patterns. Popularly used in connection with singer and superstar Beyoncé (nicknamed Queen Bey) or for metaphorical queen bees. Honeybee was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Beetle was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A ladybug (ladybird, lady beetle), a beetle with a round, red shell with black spots. Generally depicted as a seven- or nine-spotted ladybug shown from above on its six legs, with antennae and its distinctively red-and-black, halved shell. May be used a symbol of good luck. Facebook’s ladybug is shown on its legs facing forward. Lady Beetle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A cricket, a hopping insect that makes a chirping sound. Depicted as a brown or green cricket in full profile on its six legs facing left, with long antennae and large, bent back legs. May resemble or be used to represent a grasshopper (including locusts) and other bugs. May also be used to represent metaphorical crickets, or "silence," as of a disapproving or uninterested audience. Not to be confused with 🏏 Cricket Game, the sport. Google's cricket was previously green. Cricket was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
Cockroach was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A spider, an eight-legged arachnid that spins a web. Depicted as a common black spider, as a house spider or funnel-web spider, shown from above with its large abdomen oriented at the bottom. See also 🕸️ Spider Web. Commonly used during Halloween and to represent the superhero Spider-Man. Google's spider is upside down, suspended from a thread. Facebook’s spider is shown on its eight legs facing left. Microsoft’s spider was previously a black widow, Samsung’s was brown. Spider was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A classic spider web (cobweb), as spun by a 🕷️ Spider to catch prey. Depicted as a white, symmetrical, wheel-shaped web, as an orb web, with six or eight equal sectors. Commonly used during Halloween, to represent the superhero Spider-Man, or for a metaphorical web, net, or network. Not to be confused with ❄️ Snowflake. Spider Web was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A scorpion, an arachnid with lobster-like pincers and a stinging tail. Depicted as a light-brown scorpion from above, often facing left, with its pincers and curving stinger raised. Shown with six or, accurately, eight legs in addition to its pincers. Often used to represent ♏ Scorpio in the Western zodiac. WhatsApp’s scorpion is reddish in color, as is Microsoft’s stinger. Scorpion was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A mosquito, a type of bloodsucking fly. Depicted as a brown or black mosquito on its six, long legs, with wings, long abdomen, and needle-like mouth. Variously shown from above or facing left. May be used to represent various insects, other bugs and bug bites, and insect-borne diseases (e.g., malaria). May also be used for metaphorical pests. Microsoft and Facebook’s mosquitoes have red abdomens, as filled with blood. Mosquito was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
Fly was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Worm was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A microbe, as a bacterium grown in a 🧫 Petri Dish or observed under a 🔬 Microscope. Generally depicted as a squiggly, single-celled microorganism with prominent cilia. Color, shape, and position vary across platforms. Commonly used to represent bacteria, viruses, and germs and disease more generally. In 2020, this emoji became primarily used in reference to Coronavirus / COVID-19. Apple's version of this emoji most closely represents a virus, while others from Samsung and Twitter’s appear as bright green bacteria. Other versions of this emoji also appear mainly as bacteria: Microsoft’s is blue, Facebook’s indigo, and WhatsApp’s purple. Google’s design features five microbes in different, bright colors. Microbe was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A bouquet of brightly colored flowers. Generally depicted as a collection of pink and yellow flowers with green stems tied together. Positioned at various angles across platforms. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May also be more generally used to express such sentiments as love, appreciation, and happiness. Google’s flowers were previously all yellow, Microsoft’s roses, and Samsung’s pink and white. Bouquet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The pink flower of a cherry blossom tree. Depicted as a single, light-pink cherry blossom with five, notched petals and red-tipped stamens in a yellow or white center. A traditional symbol in Japan, where the flower is called sakura and celebrated in annual viewings. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to express such ideas as love and beauty. Also used as a pink accent color. Not to be confused with 💮 White Flower and 🌺 Hibiscus, though their applications may overlap. Cherry Blossom was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A stylized white flower. Generally depicted as a rosette-shaped cherry blossom in pink or red outline, often with a white fill. Apple, WhatsApp, and Facebook's designs feature Japanese characters roughly translating to very well done, used by teachers as a stamp for students who did exceptional work, often accompanied by a score in red. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to express such ideas as love, happiness, and beauty. Also used as a pink, white, or red accent color. Not to be confused with 🌸 Cherry Blossom and 🌺 Hibiscus, though their applications may overlap. Apple's flower previously featured a red-outlined design, Google's an orange outline. Microsoft's flower was previously black and white, Samsung and Facebook's pink and white. White Flower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A rosette, a stylized, flower-shaped decoration often presented as an award with a ribbon or (military) medal. Appears as a motif in ancient cultures. Generally depicted as a circular, yellow-and-orange flower. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to express such ideas as love, happiness, and beauty. Also used as a yellow accent color. Not to be confused with 🌼 Blossom, though their applications may overlap. WhatsApp's rosette is orange, white, and purple; Twitter's is purple and blue. Samsung's was previously pink. A non-emoji Unicode character 🏶 Black Rosette was once shown as an emoji on LG phones. Rosette was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A red rose. Depicted as a single, vertical red rose on a green stem. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to express such sentiments as love and romance. Also used as a symbol of socialism or as a red accent color. Not to be confused with 🌷 Tulip, though their applications may overlap. Samsung’s rose was previously pink. Rose was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A flower that has wilted, or is dying. Generally depicted as a limp, faded red rose drooping over the to the right on a dried-out, green stem, shedding a petal. May be used to express such sad sentiments as heartbreak, though sometimes with a sense of irony. Sometimes used to represent a rose or other flower, with positive connotations. Not to be confused with 🌹 Rose. WhatsApp's flower suggests a wilted 🌻 Sunflower; Twitter's a 🌷 Tulip, as Microsoft and Samsung's previously did. Facebook's flower was previously orange. Wilted Flower was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A pink hibiscus, a flower that grows in warm climates. Depicted as a single, deep-pink hibiscus flower with green leaves and prominent, yellow stamen. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to convey such ideas as love, happiness, and beauty. Also used as a pink accent color and in association with Hawaii and other Polynesian places and cultures. Google and Samsung's hibiscus flowers were previously orange. Hibiscus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sunflower, a tall, round flower with large yellow petals. Depicted as a single, vertical sunflower with a large, dark-brown center on a green stem. Commonly used for Mother’s Day and other special occasions. May be more generally used to convey such sentiments happiness and love. Also used as a yellow accent color and in association with summer and farming. Not to be confused with 🌼 Blossom, which is yellow on many platforms. Sunflower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A flower that has blossomed. Depicted as a flower with white or yellow petals, as a daisy, with a golden center. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to convey such ideas as love, appreciation, and happiness. Also used as a yellow or white accent color. Not to be confused with 🌻 Sunflower or 🌸 Cherry Blossom, though their applications may overlap. Google's flower was once pink. Microsoft's was previously yellow, Samsung's white. Blossom was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A pink tulip flower. Depicted as a single, vertical pink tulip on a green stem. Commonly used for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, and other special occasions. May be more generally used to express such sentiments as love, appreciation, and happiness. Also used in association with the Netherlands and as a pink accent color. Not to be confused with 🌹 Rose, though their applications may overlap. Google's tulip was once orange, Microsoft and Samsung's red. Tulip was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A seedling, or a young plant, as a newly sprouted tree. Depicted as a tiny, light-green plant with a short stem and two leaves. Often shown freshly sprung from a small mound of brown earth. May be used for various content concerning plant life. May also be used as a symbol of spring or representation of various types of new growth. Not to be confused with 🌿 Herb, though their applications may overlap. Facebook’s seedling previously had three leaves. Seedling was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Potted Plant was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

An evergreen tree, which keeps green leaves all year round. Depicted as a tall, dark green, cone-shaped tree with shaggy, layered leaves, as a pine or fir, showing a brown trunk. May be decorated in the form of a 🎄 Christmas Tree. May also be used to represent various types of trees, forests, northern climates, nature, winter, and the Christmas season. Evergreen Tree was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A deciduous tree, whose leaves change color before shedding, as 🍂 Fallen Leave, in the fall/autumn. Depicted as a generic tree with a round, lush, leafy top and brown trunk. May be used to represent various types of trees, forests, temperate climates, nature, and the seasons of spring and summer. Deciduous Tree was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A palm tree, a tree-like plant, as grows by the sea. Depicted as a palm tree with long, green, feather-like leaves and a tall, brown, segmented trunk. May be used to represent beaches, tropical climates and cultures, summer fun, and vacations (holidays). Vendors implement a similar tree in their 🏝️ Desert Island. Microsoft’s palm tree bears coconuts, as Samsung’s previously did. Apple’s palm tree previously had more erect palms. Palm Tree was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A cactus, a spiky plant that grows in very dry regions. Depicted as a light-green saguaro cactus with two side arms covered in spines. May be used to represent various succulents, deserts, Southwestern culture, or the Wild West. WhatsApp’s cactus is topped with three red flowers. Cactus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A rice plant, as grown before harvesting and processing. Depicted as a sheaf of Asian rice with green leaves and yellow seed heads drooping over to the right or left. May be consumed in the form of 🍚 Cooked Rice. May be used to represent a variety of cereal grains (e.g., wheat, corn, oats, sorghum) as well as crops, fields and harvests, and farming more generally. Sheaf of Rice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Ear of Rice” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An herb, a plant used in cooking or medicine. Depicted as a green sprig, as of basil, sage, or oregano, generally with five or seven leaves. May be used for various content concerning cooking, herbal medicine, and plant life more generally. Occasionally used as slang for marijuana. Not to be confused with 🌱 Seedling, though their applications may overlap. Herb was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A shamrock, a clover-like plant. Depicted as a bright green sprig with three, heart-shaped leaves. An emblem of Ireland and symbol of St. Patrick, said to use the shamrock to explain the Christian concept of the Holy Trinity. Commonly used on St. Patrick’s Day and in association with Irish culture and heritage. Not to be confused with 🍀 Four Leaf Clover, though their applications may overlap. Shamrock was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A four-leaf clover, a symbol of good luck. Depicted as a bright green sprig of clover, with four, heart-shaped leaves. Not to be confused with the three-leaf ☘️ Shamrock. Four Leaf Clover was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The distinctive, star-shaped leaf of the maple tree. Depicted as a reddish-orange maple leaf, as has changed color in the fall/autumn, with five pointed segments. Used as an emblem of Canada, featured on the 🇨🇦 Flag of Canada. Also used to represent trees and the season of fall/autumn more generally. Microsoft's leaf was previously yellow. Maple Leaf was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Leaves, as a have changed color and fallen from a tree in fall/autumn. Depicted as two or three golden-brown, almond-shaped leaves of various sizes, with stems up, as if falling down. Commonly used to represent the season of fall/autumn, trees, and nature more generally. Not to be confused with 🍃 Leaf Fluttering in Wind, though their applications may overlap. Apple’s design previously featured two leaves. Google, Microsoft, Samsung, and Facebook all once featured a single leaf. Fallen Leaf was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Leaves, as fluttering in a spring or summer breeze. Depicted as one or two green, almond-shaped leaves, with gray or blue motion lines, as if swirling in the air or as the wind blowing through the trees. May be used to represent the season of fall/autumn, trees, and nature more generally. Not to be confused with 🍂 Fallen Leaf, though their applications may overlap. Leaf Fluttering in Wind was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A grape bunch, as cut from the vine and used to make wine. Depicted as red (purple-colored) grapes. Grapes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A melon fruit in a light greenish-brown rind. Depicted as a cantaloupe by most platforms, but can resemble a honeydew at a distance. Melon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A slice of watermelon, showing its rich pink flesh, black seeds, and green rind. Watermelon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An orange-colored citrus fruit with a green leaf or leaves and stem. Officially depicting a tangerine, a type of mandarin (mikan in Japan). Often used as a garden-variety orange. Either way, a good source of vitamin C. Tangerine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The sour, yellow-colored citrus fruit of the lemon, usually with a stem and green leaf or leaves. Spiked in use thanks to Beyoncé’s 2016 album, Lemonade. Lemon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A ripe banana, peeled and ready to eat on major platforms. Great snack for a child or monkey. Banana was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The tropical fruit of a pineapple, shown in spiky, golden-brown skin and with a pointed, green crown. Positioned upright or at a 45° angle. Pineapple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The ripe fruit of a tropical mango. Variously depicted in shades of yellow, red, orange, and green with a single, green leaf and stem. Mango was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A classic red apple, shown with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms. Commonly associated with doctors, teachers, and New York. Red Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A common green apple, tarter counterpart to the Red Apple. Displayed with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms. Green Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A light-green variety of a common pear, shown with a stem and sometimes green leaf. May be used for its namesake expression, pear-shaped (“prominent hips” or “failure”). Pear was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The fleshy, pinkish-orange fruit of the fuzzy peach, shown with green leaves and sometimes a stem. Thanks to its distinctive cleft, the emoji is most commonly used for “buttocks.” In certain contexts, the peach emoji may refer to impeachment. Peach was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two rich red cherries with a green leaf and joined at their long stems. May be used to refer to male or female genitalia. Cherries was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The fruit of a rich red strawberry dotted with seeds and crowned with green leaves. Google previously depicted the fruit in orange. Strawberry was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Blueberries was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A kiwifruit, or Chinese gooseberry, with its fuzzy, brown skin sliced open to show its light-green flesh, white core, and black seeds. May be associated with New Zealand, whose residents are nicknamed Kiwis, after the bird. Kiwi Fruit was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Kiwifruit” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
A plump, red garden tomato topped with a leafy green stem. May resemble the red apple at small sizes. Tomato was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An olive shown either a singular olive fruit, or an olive branch with multiple olives. Olive was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The hairy shell of a tropical coconut, cracked in a half to show its milky-white meat. Google displays a whole coconut alongside a half-shell. Coconut was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A pear-shaped avocado, sliced in half to show its yellow-green flesh and large brown pit. Ready for toast, guacamole, or millennial jokes. Avocado was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A long, bulbous, bright purple eggplant, or aubergine in British English, shown with a leafy stem. Considered lucky in Japan to dream of an eggplant the first night of the New Year. Widely used to represent a penis. Due to its phallic use, the hashtag #🍆 was once banned (2015) on Instagram's search function. Eggplant was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Aubergine” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A whole potato—such as a russet, used for baking, mashing, or frying—shown with a few eyes on its golden-brown skin. Not to be confused with the roasted sweet potato. Potato was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A whole, bright orange carrot, topped with long green leaves, as if freshly plucked from the garden. Some platforms feature a longer, thinner carrot, others a shorter, more bulbous one. Carrot was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
An ear of corn, or maize, partially husked to show its buttery-yellow kernels. Ear of Corn was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Ear of Maize” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A bright red Mexican chili pepper, slightly curled and with a green stem. May be used to represent something “hot and spicy,” figuratively or literally, as a dish on a restaurant menu. Hot Pepper was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Bell Pepper was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A long, green cucumber with bumpy skin. Resembles its derived product, a pickle or gherkin, on many platforms, except on Apple and WhatsApp, which depict it with light-green, seed-y slices. Cucumber was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A head of a rich green leaf vegetable, usually shown with white stalks. May be used to represent a variety of greens, including romaine lettuce, chard, and Chinese cabbage like bok choy, as commonly cooked in Asian cuisines. Leafy Green was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
A rich green, tree-like head or floret of broccoli. Broccoli was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
Garlic was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Onion was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
The edible fungus of the mushroom, depicted as a toadstool with a white-spotted red cap and stem. Mushroom was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The pod of the peanut, shown in its rounded, grooved, light-brown shell. Apple depicts a pair. May be used for peanut butter as well as other edible nuts (e.g., almonds) or metaphorical ones, including slang for “crazy” and “testicle.” Peanuts was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The reddish-brown, acorn-shaped chestnut, tapering to a sharp tip from its light brown base on most platforms. A popular roasted snack associated with autumn and Christmas. May be used for other edible nuts (e.g., walnuts) or sexual slang. Chestnut was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A loaf of white or wheat bread, as before it is sliced for toast or sandwiches. Bread was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The flaky, golden-brown crescent of a croissant, a breakfast pastry associated with France and Austria. Croissant was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The long, thin loaf of a baguette, with scoring on its golden-brown crust. A bread commonly associated with France. Baguette Bread was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
A flat type of cornbread. Common types include arepa or gordita. Flatbread was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

The heart-shaped twist of a hard or soft golden-brown pretzel, seasoned with grains of salt. A snack commonly associated with Germany. Pretzel was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

The brown bread of a bagel, shown sliced in two halves. Some platforms depict seeds, as sesame or poppy, and a schmear of cream cheese, with the bagel assembled as a sandwich. May resemble the Doughnut at small sizes. After complaints, Apple updated the bagel emoji design during the iOS 12.1 beta cycle. Bagel was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A stack of breakfast pancakes, topped with a pad of butter and maple syrup oozing down its golden-brown sides, onto a plate on some platforms. Associated with the Christian observance of Shrove Tuesday, or "Pancake Day." Pancakes was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
Waffle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A wedge of yellow-orange cheese with holes, like a Swiss, but used for the food in general. May be used for various cheese-related slang expressions (e.g., “cheesy,” “say cheese,” “big cheese”). Cheese Wedge was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A hunk of unspecified meat on a white bone, as associated with cartoon cavepersons or food in anime and manga (Japanese ano niku, “that meat”). This emoji was shown as a steak in Android 4.4. Meat on Bone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A crispy brown leg (drumstick) of chicken, duck, turkey, or other poultry on the bone, as roasted at Thanksgiving or Christmas dinner or fried at fast-food restaurants. Poultry Leg was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A cut of uncooked red meat, as a T-bone or rib-eye steak, with the light, white marbling of fat. May be used for sexual slang. Cut of Meat was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
Strips of crispy, fatty, reddish-brown bacon, as fried for breakfast. Depicted as a pair on most platforms. Bacon was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A burger with a beef patty, usually depicted on a sesame bun with cheese, lettuce, and tomato—making it a cheeseburger, though officially called Hamburger by Unicode. Platforms stack the ingredients in various orders. Google previously placed the cheese under the patty, a "controversy" CEO Sundar Pichai addressed in 2018. Hamburger was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Thin-cut, golden-brown French fries, served in a red carton, as at McDonald’s. Apple features Smiling Face With Smiling Eyes on its carton. French Fries was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A slice of pepperoni pizza, topped with black olives on Google. WhatsApp adds green pepper, Samsung white onion. Pizza was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Slice of Pizza” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The cooked sausage of a hot dog in a sliced bun and drizzled with yellow mustard, as eaten at a baseball game. Hot Dog was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sandwich, as eaten at lunch, made with lettuce, tomato, and cheese on slices of white or wheat bread. Apple, Google, and WhatsApp add a deli meat that resembles ham. Sandwich was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A Mexican or Tex-Mex taco on a hard or soft corn tortilla, filled with such ingredients as beef, lettuce, tomato, cheese, and onion. Apple’s design resembles a carne asada taco, with cilantro and white onion. Taco was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A Mexican or Tex-Mex burrito, featuring a wrapped flour tortilla filled with such ingredients as beef, rice, beans, cheese, tomato, lettuce, and sour cream. Served in foil on several major platforms, suggesting a Mission burrito associated with San Francisco. Not to be confused with the Stuffed Flatbread. Burrito was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Tamale was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A flatbread, like pita, stuffed with lettuce, tomato, and/or meat. Resembles a doner kebab, falafel, shawarma, or gyro sandwich, popular in the Middle East and the Mediterranean. Apple and WhatsApp add red onion and cucumber. Not to be confused with the Burrito. Stuffed Flatbread was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
Falafel was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

An egg, displayed as a chicken egg with a white or light brown shell. Commonly used at Easter time. See also: 🍳 Cooking. Egg was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

An egg with yolk frying in a skillet, as prepared sunny-side up. Though associated with breakfast, the emoji represents the general action of cooking and related concepts. Cooking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A flat, shallow, black pan with side handles, containing saffron-colored rice, vegetables, a leg of poultry, and/or shrimp and lemon slices. Commonly associated with paella, a traditional dish from Spain. May be used for eating, cooking, dining, and meals more generally. Apple's version of this emoji is considered to be representative of the traditional ingredients from Valencia. Samsung previously displayed this emoji as a Korean hot pot. Shallow Pan of Food was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A pot, as a casserole dish, filled with a warm and hearty beef or vegetable stew on most platforms. Samsung’s design resembles a bowl of ramen or other noodle dish, with chopsticks. Generally used for eating and cooking (“a meal”), and commonly associated with soup or Japanese nabe. Pot of Food was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Fondue was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A bowl with a silver spoon inside, as used to eat cereal or soup. Bowl color varies across platforms, as do contents. Android depicts breakfast cereal, WhatsApp tomato soup; Apple’s is empty. Bowl with Spoon was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

An undressed garden salad in a bowl with leafy-green lettuce and other ingredients such as tomato, red onion, and black olives. Commonly associated with healthy eating and living. Google previously displayed a hard-boiled egg, removed in 2018 to make the salad vegan-friendly. Green Salad was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The buttery-white snack of popcorn brimming in a classic red-and-white-striped carton, as enjoyed at a movie theater. May be used to express engagement (“edge of one’s seat”). Popcorn was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Butter was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A clear glass shaker of salt with a silver cap, as paired with pepper to season food when eating at a restaurant. Salt was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Salt Shaker” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A can or tin of food, depicted as tomatoes or a generic green vegetable. May be also used to represent sauce or soup. Canned Food was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A Japanese bento, a lunch box divided into portions of rice, vegetables, and meat or seafood, such as sushi or fried shrimp. Bento Box was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A Japanese senbei, or rice cracker, wrapped with a sheet of nori, or seaweed, a snack commonly enjoyed with green tea. Rice Cracker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A Japanese onigiri, a cone-shaped ball of white rice, a snack wrapped with a sheet of nori, or seaweed. Rice Ball was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A bowl of steamed white rice, a staple component of cuisine throughout Asia. Bowl color varies across platforms, though is often white. Cooked Rice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A plate of orange-brown curry with vegetables or meat, served with a mound of white rice. May represent kare-raisu, or Japanese curry, though commonly associated with India and other Asian cuisines. Curry Rice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Curry and Rice” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A bowl of steaming-hot food. Depicted as Japanese ramen (noodles in broth) with chopsticks on most platforms, though it can represent a warm meal more generally. Samsung’s design resembles Pot of Food. Steaming Bowl was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A plate of Italian spaghetti with tomato sauce, as a bolognese, with a fork twirling its long, thin noodles. Garnished with a green herb, as parsley, on some platforms. Spaghetti was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sweet potato depicted with textured purple, orange, or brown skin and sliced in half to show its golden-brown flesh. Sometimes called a yam, though they are unrelated. Not to be confused with the Potato. Commonly roasted as a snack in East Asia during winter, much as squash and pumpkin are popular in the United States during fall/autumn. Used as an offering to the full moon in Japan during the Moon Viewing harvest festival. Roasted Sweet Potato was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A skewer of three bites of Japanese oden, a winter dish made with fishcakes, tofu, konnyaku, and a variety of other ingredients, including boiled eggs. Often served as a stew or skewered and dipped into soy sauce. Resembles the Dango and may be used for other skewered foods (e.g., shish kebab, roasting marshmallows) or spears. Oden was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Japanese sushi, generally depicted as two pieces of raw pinkish-orange fish, as tuna or salmon, on white rice (nigiri). Some platforms show the cylindrical maki, a piece of seafood, vegetables, and white rice wrapped in seaweed (nori). Sushi was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A prawn or shrimp breaded and deep-fried golden-brown. Known as ebi furai in Japan but commonly called shrimp tempura and served in a bento box. Not to be confused with the Shrimp. Fried Shrimp was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A slice of Japanese narutomaki, a ridged fishcake of processed whitefish with an iconic pink swirl, often served in ramen or oden. Thanks to its distinct swirl, may be used for flair. Fish Cake with Swirl was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Fish Cake with Swirl Design” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The round, golden-brown pastry of a Chinese mooncake, a traditional delicacy and lunar symbol of the Mid-Autumn Festival. Many platforms feature a design or character imprinted on the crust, and depict a slice cut out to show a brown paste with a duck egg yolk inside. Twitter displays the Chinese character for “fall/autumn” or “harvest” (秋) on top. Moon Cake was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A Japanese sweet dumpling made from rice flour and served on a skewer. Depicted as a botchan dango, comprising a pink, white or light yellow, and green ball, as colored by red beans, egg, and green tea. Resembles the Oden and featured in the Moon Viewing Ceremony, used in the Japanese festival to celebrate the full moon. Dango was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dumpling of dough and filling, as folded and pinched closed for steaming or frying. Associated with cuisines around the world, including China (jiaozi), Japan (gyoza or dango), Poland (pierogi), and Spain and Latin America (empanada). Facebook's design resembles a xiaolongbao, a Chinese soup dumpling. Dumpling was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A golden-brown, crescent-shaped, vanilla-flavored fortune cookie. Usually depicted with a strip of paper—on which a wise saying, lucky numbers, or Chinese vocabulary is written—peaking out of its hollow shell. Given at the end of meals at Chinese restaurants in the West. Fortune Cookie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A tall, folded, paper carton, usually white, as used for takeout/takeaway food at Western Chinese restaurants. Most platforms depict chopsticks inside its open lid, labeled with a red, multi-tiered, traditional Chinese building. Also called an oyster pail. Takeout Box was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A crab, a squat crustacean with pincers. Depicted as a reddish-orange crab (as cooked) shown from above, with a round, shelled body, shorted, tentacle-like eyes, and ten legs, the top two of which are large pincers. May be used to represent crab as food or metaphorical senses of crab (e.g., crabby). Often used to represent ♋ Cancer, the Crab, in the Western zodiac. Not to be confused with 🦞 Lobster. Facebook’s pincers have black tips. Crab was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A lobster, a large crustacean with a prominent tail and pincers. Depicted as a reddish-orange lobster (as cooked) from above, with a long body and tail, short, tentacle-like eyes, and ten legs, the top of which are very large pincers. Often used to represent lobster as food as well as in connection to the US state of Maine. In its release year of 2018, Emojipedia’s original sample image was criticized as anatomically incorrect but was shortly after resolved. That year, the transgender community embraced the lobster as a symbol for their efforts for Transgender Flag emoji. Samsung, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s lobsters are depicted at an angle. Lobster was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A shrimp (prawn), a small crustacean with a long tail. Generally depicted as a reddish-orange shrimp (as cooked) in full profile facing left, with tiny eyes, many limbs, and its long antennae curling back as its long tail curls in. May be consumed in the form of 🍤 Fried Shrimp or 🥘 Shallow Pan of Food. Often used to represent seafood. The antennae of Apple’s shrimp curls under its body. The body of Facebook’s shrimp is straight. Google and Samsung’s shrimp previously faced right. Shrimp was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A squid, an octopus-like sea animal with ten arms. Generally depicted as a pinkish-orange giant squid, facing forward or angled to the left, with a slender, arrow-like body, small eyes, and two, long arms raised up at its sides. Platforms generally depict six arms. Occasionally used to represent squid as a food item. Not to be confused with 🐙 Octopus, though their applications may overlap. Microsoft, WhatsApp, and Twitter’s squids are facing forward. Samsung’s squid was previously gray. Squid was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

An oyster, a mollusk used for food or pearls. Depicted as half of an opened oyster with a pinkish body in a rough, brown-and-white shell, bearing a pearl on many platforms. Oyster was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A swirl of soft-serve ice cream atop a wafer-style cone, white or cream-colored, as vanilla, on most platforms. Facebook’s design suggests strawberry. May be used more generally for ice cream, frozen yogurt, and frozen treats. Soft Ice Cream was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A mound of shaved ice (snow cone) served in a dessert bowl with a short spoon, flavored with a cherry-red syrup on many platforms. Associated with Hawaiian shave ice or Japanese kakigori. Shaved Ice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

One or more scoops of ice cream in a dessert bowl, variously topped with sprinkles, wafer rolls, or cherry and syrup. Flavors vary from vanilla, chocolate, and/or strawberry across platforms. Ice Cream was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A chocolate-glazed donut (or doughnut) with rainbow sprinkles. WhatsApp features a pink glaze associated with The Simpsons. May resemble the Bagel at small sizes. Doughnut was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A golden-brown chocolate chip cookie, or biscuit, though representing the baked treat more generally. Samsung, which features a pair of cookies, previously displayed this as two saltine crackers. Cookie was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A frosted cake with lit candles, as presented for a birthday celebration. The style of cake widely varies across platforms. With white frosting and strawberries, Apple and Google’s designs suggest a Japanese Christmas cake. Other vendors depict a chocolate, pink, and/or sponge cake. Birthday Cake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A slice of strawberry shortcake, layered with whipped cream and topped with a whole strawberry. Like the Birthday Cake, may be used to represent birthday celebrations or cake in general. Shortcake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An individual cupcake in a liner topped with a swirl of frosting and sprinkles. The style of cupcake widely varies across platforms. The cake may be sponge or chocolate, the frosting pink or white, and the sprinkles rainbow or red. Cupcake was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A baked dish with a pastry crust, filled with sweet or savory ingredients. Appearance widely varies by platform. Apple depicts a whole pie in a tin, its crimped crust scored to let out steam. Google shows a slice of pumpkin pie as served at Thanksgiving, WhatsApp and Twitter a slice of cherry pie. Pie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A block of dark chocolate, usually shown in a red foil wrapper peeled back to show squares of the candy. WhatsApp displays the wrapper in purple, a color commonly associated with Cadbury chocolate. Chocolate Bar was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A small piece of round, hard sugar candy, as handed out on Halloween, wrapped with two twists on its ends. Candy and wrapper color vary widely by platform. Facebook’s design resembles a classic, unwrapped red-and-white peppermint. May also be called sweets or lollies. Candy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A colorful swirl of hard candy on a stick, called a lollipop. Color varies widely by platform: Google displays rainbow colors, Android shades of pink, and Samsung a candy-cane-colored pinwheel. "Lollipop" was the name of version 5 of Google's Android operating system. Lollipop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A golden-yellow custard dessert, as a crème caramel or flan, topped with a layer of caramel. Shown on a plate, molded in a ramekin-shape and often in a pool of caramel sauce. Custard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A golden-yellow pot of honey, as made by bees and desired by bears. Shown with the sweet substance oozing down its sides, often with a honey dipper inside the small vessel. May be used figuratively, as the term of endearment “honey.” Honey Pot was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A bottle of milk or formula, as or fed to a baby, with a bluish cap and rubber nipple or teat. Positioned upright or at a 45° angle, and filled to various levels, sometimes showing fill lines. Often used for newborns and childrearing. See also Breast-Feeding. Baby Bottle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A tall glass of white milk, as from a cow but also other mammals, nuts, or plants. Most platforms depict a glass filled near to the brim, but some show a glass half-full—or half-empty. Glass of Milk was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A cup of a steaming-hot beverage, usually taken as coffee or tea. Sometimes shown on a saucer. Samsung features a foamy-white tulip latte art design. May be paired with the Frog Face to represent the snarky But That's None of My Business meme. Hot Beverage was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Teapot was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A cup of green tea, as the minty-colored Japanese matcha, usually shown on a wooden mat. Matcha is traditionally served in a small bowl that resembles a cup without a handle. Often taken as a bowl of soup, such as a split pea. Teacup Without Handle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Japanese sake, an alcoholic beverage made from rice. Shown as a sake set with a carafe (tokkuri) and drinking cup (choko). Color varies widely by platform, with Apple, WhatsApp, and Twitter featuring blue, a traditional ceramic color. Samsung displays the Japanese script for “sake” in red. Sake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Sake Bottle and Cup” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A green bottle of champagne or sparkling wine with label, its cork popping to shoot out its bubbly contents. Used for a range of celebratory occasions, such as New Year's Eve, birthdays, weddings, or other life accomplishments. Bottle with Popping Cork was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Red wine served in a stemmed glass. Google previously displayed an orange-colored drink that resembled cognac. Wine Glass was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A stemmed glass with a cone-shaped bowl, used for serving cocktails. Depicted as a martini garnished with an olive. Might be gin or vodka, shaken or stirred. See also Tropical Drink. Cocktail Glass was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sunset-orange-colored tropical beverage in a stemmed glass, as a rum punch or mai tai. Served with a straw and fruit garnish. Many platforms include a cocktail umbrella, hence umbrella drink. Samsung previously featured an electric-blue concoction. See also Cocktail Glass. Tropical Drink was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A beer, as a golden-colored lager, in a frosty mug. Depicted with a frothy head spilling over the brim. Clinking Beer Mugs is a variation that displays two such beer mugs. Beer Mug was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two frosty mugs of beer with frothy heads being clinked together, as done at a celebratory or convivial toast (“Cheers!”). Several platforms include stylized lines to mark the clinking. See also Clinking Glasses. Clinking Beer Mugs was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two flutes of champagne or sparkling wine being clinked together, as done at a celebratory or convivial toast (“Cheers!”). Samsung’s design suggests two glasses of white wine. Some platforms include stylized links to mark the clinking. See also Clinking Beer Mugs—and Bottle With Popping Cork for a refill. Clinking Glasses was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A short, flat glass, as used for brown liquors like whiskey or Scotch whisky. Apple and WhatsApp serve theirs neat, while other platforms include ice ("on the rocks"). Samsung's glass features the faint initials ONI, an apparent in-company easter egg. Tumbler Glass was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A drinking cup with a straw. Depicted on many platforms as a disposable cup with a lid and bendy straw, as used to serve soft drinks at fast-food restaurants. May be used for a range of non-alcoholic beverages, including milkshakes, smoothies, juice, and to-go beverages. Color and design vary by platform. Twitter's design suggests a glass of water, Samsung displays Slightly Smiling Face on a red label. Cup with Straw was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

Bubble tea is a tea-based drink invented in Taiwan which general contain tea, flavored mlk, and sugar. Commonly served with tapioca pearls, also known as boba, in a plastic cup with a wide straw. Bubble Tea was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Beverage Box was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

Mate is a caffeinated beverage popular in many South American countries. Green in color (from a key ingredient: the dried leaves of yerba mate) and consumed via a metal straw. This drink is commonly referred to as yerba mate in English, and sometimes spelled maté (to distinguish from a mate, as in friend). Mate was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Mate Drink” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Ice was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Ice Cube” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A pair of equal-length chopsticks, an eating utensil used throughout East Asia. Design and color vary widely by platform, though often red or wood-colored and with tips angled together. Featured in many platforms' Steaming Bowl of Food and Takeout Box. A counterpart to utensils such as Fork and Knife and Spoon. Chopsticks was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

A silver fork and knife on either side of a white plate, as set for dinner or another meal. Often used more generally for eating and dining. May be paired with Spoon. Fork and Knife with Plate was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A silver fork to the left of a knife, silverware or cutlery used to eat a meal. Often used more generally for eating and dining. May be paired with Spoon or used with Fork and Knife With Plate. Fork and Knife was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A silver spoon, as used to eat soup, cereal, or ice cream as well as serve food or stir drinks. Positioned at various angles across platforms. May be paired with Fork and Knife, Fork and Knife With Plate, and Bowl With Spoon. Spoon was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A knife with a long steel blade, as a chef uses to slice meat or vegetables. Depicted with a black or brown handle and positioned at a 45° angle, often with its point at the lower right. May be used for content concerning cooking and food preparation, but often represents various senses of cutting and stabbing. Its Unicode name, Hocho, means “kitchen knife” in Japanese and refers to a variety of knives used in Japan. Not to be confused with 🗡️ Dagger or ⚔️ Crossed Swords. Kitchen Knife was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Hocho” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A tall, ceramic jar with two handles and a narrow neck and foot. Represents an amphora, as used by ancient Greeks and Romans to hold water and wine. Generally depicted as brownish-red earthenware ornamented with black and a Greek meander pattern. May represent containers like vases, pottery, museums, history, and antiquity. May also be used in relation to the zodiac sign of Aquarius, the Water-Bearer. Not to be confused with ⚱️ Funeral Urn. Amphora was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A globe, showing the continents of Europe and Africa in green against blue ocean. May be used to represent various content concerning the European, African, and Atlantic regions. May also be used to represent Earth and international affairs more generally. See also 🌎 Globe Showing Americas and 🌏 Globe Showing Asia-Australia. Globe Showing Europe-Africa was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Earth Globe Europe-Africa” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A globe, showing the continents of North and South America in green against blue ocean. May be used to represent various content concerning the North and South American regions as well Atlantic and Pacific regions. May also be used to represent Earth and international affairs more generally. See also 🌍 Globe Showing Europe-Africa and 🌏 Globe Showing Asia-Australia. Globe Showing Americas was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Earth Globe Americas” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A globe, showing the continents of Asia and Australia in green against blue ocean. May be used to represent various content concerning the Asian, Australian, and Pacific regions. May also be used to represent Earth and international affairs more generally. See also 🌎 Globe Showing Americas and 🌍 Globe Showing Europe-Africa. Globe Showing Asia-Australia was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Earth Globe Asia-Australia” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A stylized globe, with blue meridians (longitudes) and latitude. Depicted with light-blue grid of lines on a white, blue, or empty circle. May be used as a symbol of the internet or world wide web, global communications, international affairs, connectivity and networks, time zones, coordinates, or the world more generally. May appear as an icon on Apple devices to change (language) keyboards. See also 🌎 Globe Showing Americas, 🌍 Globe Showing Europe-Africa, and 🌏 Globe Showing Asia-Australia. Globe with Meridians was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A rectangular map of the world. Generally depicted as a paper map creased at its folds, Earth’s surface shown in green on blue ocean. Commonly represent maps, travel, exploration, and geography. May also represent various content concerning the world as a whole, e.g., global or international issues. Microsoft and Samsung’s design previously depicted outlines of the continents. World Map was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Shows a map of the country of Japan, which is the only country to have its own emoji map. Other countries can be found on the various globe emojis, or the world map emoji. Map of Japan was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Silhouette of Japan” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A magnetic compass, as used for navigation. Generally depicted in a silver or gold case with a compass rose and a red-tipped needle. Commonly used for various content concerning traveling and exploring as well as metaphorical compasses (e.g., moral compass). Google and Facebook’s markings include the initials of the four cardinal directions, north, south, east, and west. Not to be confused with various clock or timepiece emojis. Compass was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A mountain with snow resting at higher altitudes. Similar in appearance to the Mount Fuji emoji. Snow-Capped Mountain was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Snow Capped Mountain” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A mountain shown with two peaks and blue sky. Similar to the snow capped mountain emoji. Mountain was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A volcano, erupting with smoke and lava. Volcano was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Mount Fuji (called Fuji-san in Japan) is the largest mountain in Japan. Often seen with snow on the peak in colder months of the year. It is considered lucky in Japan to dream of Mt Fuji in the first dream of the new year. Mount Fuji was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A campsite featuring a tent and a tree, and perhaps a campfire. Similar to the tent emoji. Camping was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A beach showing sand, and an umbrella for protection from the sun. Beach with Umbrella was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Desert was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Desert Island was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A national park, generally displayed with mountains, a river or stream, and trees. National Park was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A large capacity stadium, featuring a large amount of seating for sporting fans, or people attending other shows hosted by the stadium. Stadium was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Classical Building was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A construction site generally depicted as a tower crane shown lifting steel or other building materials. Building Construction was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A red brick or bricks. Depicted in a loose stack, a single object with holes, or as built into wall, as of a house, school, or other structure. Commonly used for various content concerning building and construction. May also be used for figurative bricks, e.g., slang brick, “extremely cold (weather).” Brick was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A large rock the size of a small (emoji-sized) rock. May be considered a boulder, though the exact size or scale is unknown. Color varies, usually a gray or brown shade. May also be used to represent stones or dirt, in the absense of emojis for these concepts. Rock was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Wood was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Hut was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Multiple houses. Houses was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “House Buildings” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A house which is unoccupied, and has become derelict. In a state of disrepair. Derelict House was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Derelict House Building” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A house, otherwise known as a home when someone is living in it. Suitable for a couple or larger family, other perhaps housemates. Distinct from an apartment building due to its detached form, this house is likely in the suburbs of a city or a rural area. House was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “House Building” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A suburban-looking house, with a tree, flower, or shrubs around it in the garden. House with Garden was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A generic, high-rise office building. Generally found in cities, and most active during business hours. The office building shown in Twemoji 2.0 is of Twitter HQ in San Fransisco. Office Building was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A Japanese post office, featuring the テ Japanese postal mark on the front of the building (or showing this mark instead of the building in Microsoft’s artwork). Japanese Post Office was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A European-style post office. A postal horn can be seen on the front, which is commonly found in the logos of European Postal Services. Post Office was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “European Post Office” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A place where people are taken to receive medical care. This hospital has a large red cross on the front, often used as a symbol for health care. Hospital was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A retail bank branch, where people can perform money-related tasks. Also a common location to find an ATM. This emoji came to also mean "slacking off" or evading responsibility in Japan, due to the BK letters being associated with the slang term bakkureru. Bank was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A hotel building, displayed on most platforms as a building with many windows and a letter H on the front. Can be easily confused with the Love Hotel, or Hospital emoji. Microsoft this emoji as a bed, when viewed using Windows. Hotel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A love hotel is a hotel that can be hired by the hour instead of as accommodation for the evening. Sometimes mistaken for a get well soon emoji due to the similarity in appearance to the hospital. The Microsoft version of this emoji previously displaying a bed with a heart above it. Love Hotel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A shop that is generally open for longer hours than a regular supermarket, sometimes 24 hours per day. Sells a range of goods from snacks, meals, hygiene products and household items. Convenience Store was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A school building with multiple storeys, and a clock on the front. A place that children, or teenagers attend for their education. Displays on Windows as a collection of school-related items: an apple, ruler, and pencil. School was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A large department store, selling a range of products to the general public. Shown as a large building with a billboard on most platforms, or as a shopping bag on Windows. Department Store was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An industrial factory, with flue-gas stacks releasing exhaust into the air. Factory was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A traditional Japanese Castle, usually made from stone and wood. Japanese Castle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A castle, in a style that can be found in France and other parts of Europe. Castle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “European Castle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An emoji to depict a wedding, displayed by most vendors as a Christian church and love hearts. Some platforms display a cross or bell on the building. Wedding was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Tokyo Tower is the second-tallest building in Japan, located in Minato, Tokyo. Built in 1957, the design of the Tokyo Tower  was inspired by the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France and may be confused for it due to the small size of the emoji. Tokyo Tower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Statue of Liberty, often used as a depiction of New York City. Statue of Liberty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A church building, generally associated with Christian denominations. In addition quiet prayer, churches hold regular worship services, weddings, baptisms and funerals. Church was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A mosque building, a place of worship for followes of Islam. Shown with a domed roof and a minaret. Mosque was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Hindu Temple was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
A synague; a place of worship for followers of Judaism. Displayed with a Star of David on the front. Synagogue was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A shrine used for the Japanese Shinto religion. This emoji generally displays the torii, which is the gate to the Shinto Shrine. The torii is generally a red colored structure, with a curved roof section above two posts. This icon is used on maps in Japan to represent the location of a Shinto Shrine, similar to how the hot springs emoji is the icon used on Japanese maps to show the location of an onsen. Shinto Shrine was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A cube-shaped building located at the centre of the Al-Masjid al-Haram Mosque in Mecca. Kaaba was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A water fountain, found in a park or other public space. Used for decorative purposes. A variety of styles of fountain are shown across different platforms. Fountain was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A tent, used for protection from wind and rain when camping. Often shown at night time, under stars. Tent was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Foggy weather displayed as fog covering a bridge or cityscape, depending on the platform. For platforms that show a bridge, the red Golden Gate Bridge is generally displayed. Foggy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A night sky with stars, depicted on major platforms as a cityscape at night. Night with Stars was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Cityscape was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The sun rising over a mountain range, early in the morning. Sunrise Over Mountains was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A sun rising, early in the morning. Can be difficult to distinguish from a sunset in some versions of this artwork. Sunrise was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A view of city buildings as the last light disappears from the sky. An orange (or blue) glow lingers, before the stars of the night sky become visible. Cityscape at Dusk was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A beautiful view, featuring an orange sky, with the sun setting over the buildings of a city skyline. Sunset was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Sunset Over Buildings” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A lit-up bridge, shown at night. Bridge at Night was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Representation of hot springs with steam rising from a circular tub. This is the common symbol used to represent an onsen on maps in Japan. Hot Springs was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A wooden painted horse, found on the carousel at a carnival. Faces to the left-of screen. A previous version of Windows displayed the carousel horse facing right, which was changed to face left on Windows 10 for cross-platform consistency. Carousel Horse was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A large rotating wheel, often found at a carnival or fair. Ferris Wheel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A roller coaster in a theme park going down a dip in the ride. Three carriages can be seen with two people in each red carriage. Roller Coaster was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A pole spiraled with red, white, and blue stripes, as spins out front of a barbershop. Commonly used for various content concerning haircutting and hairstyling. May also be associated with brothels in parts of Asia. Barber Pole was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A circular ‘big top’ circus tent, with a triangle flag on top. Circus Tent was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A steam train, powered by coal or wood. An early type of locomotive, now mostly replaced by electric or diesel trains. Oddly, this emoji does not show any steam coming from the train. Locomotive was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Steam Locomotive” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A railway (railroad) car (carriage) that is generally pulled along a railway line by a locomotive. Shown with a pantograph above the carriage on many platforms which makes it look more like a tram car. Google’s artwork previously looked like a bus and Microsoft's older versions appeared similar to a minecart. Railway Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A high speed train, designed to cover long distances at high speed. High-Speed Train was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A high speed train, designed to cover long distances at high speed. Also features a streamlined bullet nose, often used in reference to the Shinkansen in Japan. Bullet Train was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “High-Speed Train with Bullet Nose” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A train, of no specified type. Due to the presence of a steam train and fast train emoji, this is likely to be a regular electrified or diesel passenger train. Train was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A metro: frequent underground train found in built-up areas with high populations. This emoji is generally displayed as a forward-facing train, with some platforms also displaying a tunnel as a circle surrounding the train. Apple's artwork shows the characters IL2 which may be a reference to one of the more locked-down buildings at Apple's Infinite Loop Headquarters during iPhone development (IL2 = Infinite Loop 2). Metro was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A form of public transport similar to a tram, but running on a track or network separated from cars and other types of traffic. Difficult to discern from a train at small sizes. Light Rail was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A station, presumed to be a train station. Displays a train alongside a platform, where passengers can board. Station was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A form of public transport on rails, usually found on streets in cities or other urban areas. For short or medium-length journeys. Trams tend to be similar to light rail, with the difference being that they don’t tend to have their own dedicated tracks. This emoji is generally shown as the front of the tram, on tracks. The intended usage of this emoji, instead of the tram car emoji is not clear. Tram was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Similar to a train, but running on a single track. Monorails are often found at theme parks, or other tourist destinations. Monorail was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A train and railway in the mountains. Displayed as a funicular in Microsoft’s artwork, or a regular train on other platforms. Android displays this train front-facing, leaving a tunnel, which appears similarly to the metro emoji at small sizes. Mountain Railway was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A form of public transport on rails, usually found on streets in cities or other urban areas. For short or medium-length journeys. Trams tend to be similar to light rail, with the difference being that they don’t tend to have their own dedicated tracks. This emoji is generally shown as the side of the tram. The intended usage of this emoji, instead of the tram emoji is not clear. Tram Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A bus used for public transport in cities and towns. Could also be used as a school bus. Bus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The front of a bus, showing the windscreen, as well as wing mirrors in some versions of this emoji. Oncoming Bus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A type of bus that uses overhead electrical wires for power. Appears similar to a cross between a bus and a tram car. Trolleybus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A small bus or minivan designed to carry fewer people than a full-sized bus. Displayed in white on most platforms (green on Facebook). Minibus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An ambulance, used to transport patients between their home and the hospital. Ambulance was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A red fire truck, an essential part of emergency services along with a police car or ambulance. May be on the way to put out a fire. Fire Engine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A police car, shown with an emergency light on the top. This emoji is displayed from the side, as opposed to the oncoming police car emoji, which is shown from the front. Police Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A police car, shown with an emergency light on the top. This emoji is displayed from the front, as opposed to the police car emoji, which is shown from the side. Oncoming Police Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A yellow taxicab, iconically seen in New York City. Shown from the side, as opposed to the oncoming taxi emoji. Taxi was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A yellow taxicab, iconically seen in New York City. Shown from the front, as opposed to the taxi emoji which displays the side of the vehicle. Oncoming Taxi was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A car shown from the side, facing right-to-left. Appears as a red car on most platforms (which goes faster), except on Android where this displays as a silver car (previously blue). Automobile was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A car being shown from the front. The windscreen and hood (bonnet in British English) of the car can be seen facing forward. This car shows in red or blue on most platforms. Silver on Android. Oncoming Automobile was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A vehicle used for recreation, which is generally understood to mean a campervan or motorhome. May have originally been intended to represent an SUV, based on most versions of this emoji featuring a large vehicle with a spare tyre on the back. Sport Utility Vehicle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Recreational Vehicle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Pickup Truck was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Delivery Truck was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Articulated Lorry was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A tractor, may be used by a farmer or other occupation on the land. Tractor was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A racing car which appears as a formula one vehicle or rally car on most platforms. Generally displayed in red. Apple's version of this emoji features the Swift (programming language) logo on the side. Racing Car was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A motorcycle, otherwise known as a motorbike used for sport/racing purposes. For a transport-based motorcycle, use a motor scooter. Motorcycle was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Racing Motorcycle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A motor scooter, which may be displayed as any type of motorbike with or without a step-through frame. Distinct from the racing motorcycle, which is used for sport, not transport. Motor Scooter was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A wheelchair without any motor. Distinct from ♿ Wheelchair Symbol which is used as signage to indicate accessible facilities. See also Woman in Manual Wheelchair or Man in Manual Wheelchair. Manual Wheelchair was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
