Commonly used for various content concerning astronomy, outer space, celestial objects, and science more generally. May also be used for various concepts of sight (e.g., spying, viewing). Google and Twitter’s designs feature red hardware. Telescope was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A dish antenna, as used to send or receive information to or from a communication satellite—or 👽 Extraterrestrial Life. Generally depicted as a mounted, metal dish with its antenna positioned at 45° to the upper right. Commonly used to represent satellite television, radio, and internet, as well as broadcasting, streaming, cellular, and wireless services or technologies. May also represent various concepts of signals and transmission. Several platforms, including Samsung and Twitter, feature curved, radiating lines, as if transmitting data. Google’s design is depicted in blue. Satellite Antenna was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A medical syringe, as used to administer a shot or draw blood. Generally depicted at a 45° angle with a needle to the upper right, emitting two droplets of the red fluid in its barrel, as blood drawn for testing or donation at a hospital. Commonly used for content concerning health, medicine, and related professions as well as various senses of needles, drugs, and blood. Google and Facebook’s designs previously featured green liquids, Samsung’s syringe was empty. Syringe was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A drop of blood shown in red. May be used to signify a blood donation, bleeding, injury or menstruation. Drop of Blood was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A capsule of medicine. Generally depicted at a 45° angle, half red, half yellow. Commonly used for content concerning health, medicine, and related professions as well various types of drugs. Samsung’s design previously featured a blue-and-white capsule with two round pills, one orange, the other white. Google and Microsoft’s designs previously featured blue in their capsules. Pill was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Adhesive Bandage was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Stethoscope was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A door, as to the entrance of a room, house, or new opportunity. (We’ll see ourselves out 🚪🚶.) Depicted in brown, as made of wood, with a gold handle. May represent literal doors and related concepts (e.g., rooms, houses) but often used figuratively (e.g., opening or closing metaphorical doors). Google’s design features a peephole and Microsoft’s a step, as if a front door. Door was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Elevator was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Mirror was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Window was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A bed, made up for sleeping in a house, hotel, or other sleeping accommodation. Shown with a headboard at the left, footboard, mattress, pillow, and sheet. Most platforms suggest a wooden frame and feature blue or red sheets. Commonly used for various content concerning beds, furniture, and housing as well as sleeping, relaxing, and other bedroom activities. Vendors implement the same style of bed for 🛌 Person in Bed, but without a sleeper under the covers. Bed was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A couch (sofa) with a floor lamp on the right, as in the living room of a house. Color and style of the couch and lamp vary widely by platform. Used for various content concerning furniture and housing as well as resting and lounging. Couch and Lamp was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A chair for sitting at a table, or in a standalone location. Materials may vary, with wood a common choice. Distinct from the seat emoji, which is generally fixed, as opposed to a chair which can be moved. Chair was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A white toilet, as used to deposit a 💩 Pile of Poo. (Don’t forget the 🧻 Roll of Paper.) Most platforms depict a porcelain toilet in profile, bowl facing to the left. Commonly used for various content concerning going to the bathroom or bathrooms more generally. May also be used figuratively, e.g., down the toilet. Google, Microsoft, and Twitter’s designs left the seat up. Toilet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Plunger was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A silver shower head, streaming water to the left. Pressure level varies across platforms. 🧼 Soap not provided. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and water. Shower heads are also featured in 🛁 Bathtub and 🛀 Person Taking a Bath. Shower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A white bathtub with a silver shower head. Often depicted as a cast-iron tub with claw-foot legs. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally. Several platforms, including Apple and Facebook, feature soap bubbles or suds. Samsung’s design displays streaming water from the shower head. Vendors implement 🛀 Person Taking a Bath with the same or a similar emoji, but with a person soaking in the tub. Bathtub was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Mouse Trap was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
A razor which may be displayed as a razor blade or a safety razor. Razor was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

A bottle of lotion for the skin, such as moisturizer or sunscreen (sunblock). May be used for other hygienic liquids, including shampoo and body wash, as well as beauty products. Appearance varies across platforms, but commonly depicted in white and gold colors. Some platforms, like Apple and Twitter, feature a bottle with a pump while others show a cylinder with a cap. Lotion Bottle was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A silver safety pin or clip, as used to fasten fabric. Generally shown clasped at a 45° angle, with its spring at the lower left. May be used for various content concerning arts, crafts, and sewing. Not to be confused with 📎 Paperclip. Safety Pin was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A traditional broom, as used for sweeping—or ridden by a witch. Shown at a 45° angle, with a wooden handle and yellow bristles at the lower left. Commonly used for various content concerning cleaning, brushing, and figurative sweeps (e.g., in sports or awards). Not to be confused with 🖌️ Paintbrush. Broom was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A basket, as used for storing or carrying such things as food or clothes. Appearance widely varies across platforms but generally depicted as woven from wicker with one or more handles. Commonly used to represent doing laundry or having a picnic. Microsoft’s design suggests a laundry basket holding a blue garment or cloth. Apple and WhatsApp’s designs, featuring a white cloth, suggest a bread or picnic basket. Samsung’s design displays green fabric, as knitted from yarn. Not to be confused with 🗑️ Wastebasket. Basket was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A roll of paper, as toilet paper (toilet tissue). May also be a roll of kitchen/paper towels. Depicted at various angles, with a sheet unfurling. Commonly used for toilet paper but may also be used for various content concerning toilets, going to the bathroom, bathrooms, cleaning, or paper more generally. Roll of Paper was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
Bucket was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A bar of soap, as used in the shower, bath or for hand washing. Generally shown with lathered bubbles. Depicted in various colors, often pink, and at different angles. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning. May be used to represent the opposite of dirt or being dirty. Recommended for use to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Soap was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Bar of Soap” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
Toothbrush was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A peanut-shaped sponge, as used for cleaning or bathing. Generally depicted in yellow and at different angles across platforms. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning. Sponge was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

A fire extinguisher, as used to put out small fires. Depicted as a red tank with a black hose and pressure gauge. Most platforms include an image of a flame on a white label. Commonly used for various content concerning fire safety, emergencies, and literal and figurative fires. Fire Extinguisher was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
Shopping Cart was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Shopping Trolley” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

A lit, filtered cigarette, shown burning at different directions. Commonly used to represent various forms of smoking (e.g., tobacco, marijuana, vaping) as well as metaphorical senses of smoking. Originally intended as a sign for a designated smoking area, as contrasted to 🚭 No Smoking Symbol. This is illustrated in Samsung’s previous design of a stylized, white cigarette on a blue background. Cigarette was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Smoking Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A traditional coffin, as used to bury the dead. Depicted at various angles as a closed, six-sided, wooden coffin, tapered at the head and foot with golden handles. Commonly used for various content concerning literal and figurative death. May also be used for various content concerning funerals, horror, and Halloween. Apple and Microsoft’s designs place flowers on their lids. Coffin was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Headstone was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

An urn, as used to hold the cremated ashes of the dead. Appearance varies, but generally depicted as a covered, bronze container with a rounded body and tapered foot. May be used for various content concerning death and funerals. May also be used for other types of vessels, such as pots or vases. Not to be confused with 🏺 Amphora. Funeral Urn was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A moai, one of the famed, giant stone statues of human figures on Easter Island. Depicted as a gray stone carving of a stylized human head with a prominent brow and nose, most often facing left. Sometimes used for various idiosyncratic purposes, such as conveying a stoic, deadpan, or silly expression. Its official Unicode name of Moyai and inclusion in early Japanese emoji sets, such as from au by KDDI, suggest the emoji may represent the Moyai Statue near Shibuya Station in Tokyo, Japan; previous designs from Google and Microsoft resemble the Tokyo statue. Other Tokyo landmarks are represented in 🗼 Tokyo Tower and, formerly, Shibuya 109. Moai was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Moyai” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Placard was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
ATM Sign was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Automated Teller Machine” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol showing a person putting litter (rubbish) in the trash (rubbish bin). A more positive version of the Do Not Litter Symbol. Litter in Bin Sign was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Put Litter in Its Place Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol for potable (drinkable) water, usually shown with a faucet filling a drinking glass. Commonly used for various content concerning water, drinking, thirst, and dripping. Some platforms, including Apple and WhatsApp, depict the emoji as an object while others feature a stylized, white faucet on a blue square, as a sign or icon of water that is safe to drink. Compare 🚱 Non-Potable Water, which indicates water that is not safe to drink. Apple's design previously featured a blue symbol design, Microsoft's a cup filled with water. Potable Water was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Potable Water Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The international symbol of access, used to denote a facility which has been designed with accessibility or people in wheelchairs in mind. Appears as a blue sign, with a white graphic of a person sitting in a wheelchair. Many platforms now use the Accessible Icon Project style image for this emoji, which displays the person in the wheelchair in a more active position. Wheelchair Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A stick-figure icon of a man, generally used to indicate a male restroom. The female equivalent is the Womens Symbol emoji. Men’s Room was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Mens Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A stick-figure icon of a woman, generally used to indicate a female restroom. The male equivalent is the Mens Symbol emoji. Women’s Room was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Womens Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A restroom symbol, depicting a iconography of a man and woman. Used to indicate the location of public bathrooms / toilets / restrooms. Used as an alternative to the water closet symbol. Restroom was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The symbol for a baby, usually used to indicate a room that is suitable to change a baby in. Often located in or near public restrooms. Baby Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A water closet is a name used for public toilet, bathroom or restroom used in some countries. Typically abbreviated to the letters WC, this may be found on signage in public buildings, as an alternative to the restroom symbol. Water Closet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A person checking passports at an international border. Passport Control was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A customs officer inspecting luggage. May be shown on signage at airports or other border crossings. Not to be confused with the passport control emoji. Customs was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Baggage Claim was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An icon representing a place to leave luggage. Most commonly found at Japanese train stations to signify coin lockers where bags can be stored for a daily fee. This emoji displays a suitcase with a key above or below it, ususually in blue. Left Luggage was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A triangle with an exclamation mark inside, used as a warning or alert. Warning was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Warning Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A crossing sign for children, usually positioned near schools or other areas that drivers should be cautious of young children in the area. Children Crossing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
No Entry was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A red circle with a diagonal line through the middle, from top-left to bottom right, used to indicate that something is not permitted Commonly shown in conjunction with other symbols to indicate No Smoking, No Bikes, or similar. Prohibited was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “No Entry Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A bicycle with a red stroke through it, indicating that bikes are prohibited from this location. May be seen in pedestrian malls with a bicycle restriction or crossing train tracks in some countries. No Bicycles was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
No Smoking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “No Smoking Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A person dropping litter (rubbish, trash) with a red stroke through it, indicating that littering is prohibited in this area. Usually implied by the fact that littering is not welcome anywhere, this sign serves as a reminder in areas that are known to attract litter. No Littering was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Do Not Litter Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A water tap with a red stroke through it, indicating that water is not safe for drinking (non-potable). May be used at a camp site or other area that has water suitable for cleaning or other non-drinking purposes. Non-Potable Water was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Non-Potable Water Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A pedestrian symbol with a red stroke through it, indicating that pedestrians are prohibited from this location. May be seen in dedicated bike lanes, highways, or other areas not suitable to be on-foot. No Pedestrians was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A mobile phone with a red stroke through it, indicating that mobile phones should not be present. Often seen in restricted areas, such as Customs or Passport Control. No Mobile Phones was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The number eighteen with a red stroke through it, indicating a location where a person must be aged 18 or above to enter. Often used online to indicate adult or NSFW content. The Samsung version of this emoji previously displayed the number 19. This may have been due to the practice of counting the first year of life as one instead of zero in parts of East Asia such as South Korea (the location of the Samsung Headquarters). No One Under Eighteen was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “No One Under Eighteen Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A hazard symbol for radiation or radioactivity. May appear similar to a three-pronged fan at small sizes. Generally displayed on an orange or yellow background. Radioactive was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Radioactive Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Biohazard was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Biohazard Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An arrow, pointing up. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Up Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Upwards Black Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An arrow pointing diagonally in an up-right, or north-east direction. Up-Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “North East Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An arrow, pointing right. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Rightwards Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An arrow pointing diagonally in an down-right, or south-east direction. Down-Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “South East Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An arrow, pointing down. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Down Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Downwards Black Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An arrow pointing diagonally in an down-left, or south-west direction. Down-Left Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “South West Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An arrow, pointing left. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Left Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Leftwards Black Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
An arrow pointing diagonally in an up-left, or north-west direction. Up-Left Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “North West Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A vertical line with arrowheads on both ends, pointing up and down. Up-Down Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Up Down Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A horizontal line with arrowheads on both ends, pointing left and right. Left-Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Left Right Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An arrow pointing to the left, with a curved hook at the other end. Similar in appearance to a sideways U Turn symbol, or a reply icon in an email application. Right Arrow Curving Left was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Leftwards Arrow with Hook” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An arrow pointing to the right, with a curved hook at the other end. Similar in appearance to a sideways U Turn symbol, or a forward icon in an email application. Left Arrow Curving Right was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Rightwards Arrow with Hook” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A curved arrow pointing up. Right Arrow Curving Up was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Arrow Pointing Rightwards Then Curving Upwards” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A curved arrow pointing down. Right Arrow Curving Down was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Arrow Pointing Rightwards Then Curving Downwards” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Clockwise Vertical Arrows was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clockwise Downwards and Upwards Open Circle Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two arrows forming a circle, pointing in an anticlockwise direction. Similar to symbols sometimes used for refresh or rotate. May also be used to indicate a task is in progress. Previously showed in a clockwise direction on Windows. Counterclockwise Arrows Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Anticlockwise Downwards and Upwards Open Circle Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Back Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Back with Leftwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
End Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “End with Leftwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
On! Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “On with Exclamation Mark with Left Right Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The word "soon" with an arrow above it, pointing to the right. Soon Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Soon with Rightwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The word "top" with an arrow pointing up above it. Top Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Top with Upwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A building used for worship by people of any faith or religion. Examples include a church, mosque, or synagogue. A person is shown on their knees praying, in this symbol. Multi-faith places of worship are commonly found at airports. Place of Worship was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Atom Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A symbol often used in relation to the religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and Jainism. Om was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Om Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol often used in relation to the religion of Judaism. Not to be confused with the Six Pointed Star With Middle Dot emoji. Star of David was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A symbol often used in relation to the Indian religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and Jainism. Wheel of Dharma was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Yin Yang was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A latin cross, otherwise known as a Christian cross. This cross symbol is often used as a symbol of Christianity. Similar in appearance to the Orthodox cross. Latin Cross was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Orthodox Cross was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The crescent moon and star is a symbol often associated with the religion of Islam. This symbol can be found on the flags of many countries, such as Algeria, Azerbaijan, Malaysia, Pakistan and Turkey. Star and Crescent was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A circular symbol, commonly used as a representation of peace. Alternatives include the Victory Hand, or the Dove of Peace. Peace Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A menorah showing nine lit candles, used on the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah. Menorah was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Menorah with Nine Branches” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A star with six points, and a dot in the center. Similar to the Star of David emoji. Dotted Six-Pointed Star was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Six Pointed Star with Middle Dot” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Aries astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Ram. Aries was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Taurus astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Bull. Taurus was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Gemini astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents Twins. Gemini was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Cancer astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Crab. Cancer was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Leo astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Lion. Leo was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Virgo astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Maiden. Virgo was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Libra astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents weighing scales. Libra was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Scorpius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Scorpion. Scorpio was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Scorpius” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Sagittarius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents an Archer. Sagittarius was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Capricorn astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Goat. Capricorn was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Aquarius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Water-bearer. Aquarius was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The Pisces astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Fish. Pisces was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Ophiuchus is used by some as a 13th sign in the Zodiac. The symbol for ophiuchus appears a U shape with a wavy line through it. Ophiuchus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two arrows pointing right while crossing over one another. Used to indicate putting music on shuffle: randomizing the order of tracks in the upcoming playlist. May also be used to indicate two items switching places. Shuffle Tracks Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Twisted Rightwards Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Circular arrows pointing in a clockwise direction. Used in music player applications to loop a track or album continuously. Commonly used to repesent a retweet on Twitter. Repeat Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clockwise Rightwards and Leftwards Open Circle Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Arrows pointing in a clockwise direction, with a number 1 badge in the lower corner.  Used in music player applications to loop a track or album once. Repeat Single Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clockwise Rightwards and Leftwards Open Circle Arrows with Circled One Overlay” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing right. Commonly used as a symbol for play. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Play Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two triangles pointing to the right. Most commonly used as a symbol for fast forwarding media such as video tapes, CDs, or digital audio and video. Fast-Forward Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol used in media players to indicate skipping to the next track (or scene). Shown as two triangles pointing right followed by a vertical bar. Next Track Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Double Triangle with Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A play-pause icon, showing a right-pointing triangle (play) next to a double vertical bar (pause). Play or Pause Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Triangle with Double Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing left. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Reverse Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Left-Pointing Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two triangles pointing to the left. Most commonly used as a symbol for rewinding media such as video tapes, CDs, or digital audio and video. Fast Reverse Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Left-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol used in media players to indicate skipping to the first or previous track (or scene). Shown as a vertical bar followed by two triangles pointing left. Last Track Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Left-Pointing Double Triangle with Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing up. Styled similarly to the left and right pointing triangles on iOS, but shown in red on Windows, and orange on Android. Upwards Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Up-Pointing Small Red Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two triangles pointing up. Similar to rewind icon, rotated 90° clockwise. Fast Up Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Up-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing down. Styled similarly to the left and right pointing triangles on iOS, but shown in red on Windows, and orange on Android. Downwards Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Down-Pointing Small Red Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two triangles pointing down. Similar to rewind icon, rotated 90° counter-clockwise. Fast Down Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Down-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A pause icon, displayed as two vertical bars. Pause Button was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Double Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A stop icon, displayed as a square. Stop Button was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Black Square for Stop” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A record icon, displayed as a circle. Record Button was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Black Circle for Record” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An eject symbol, displayed as an upward-pointing triangle above a horiztonal bar. May be used as a physical button or an icon in a user interface. Represents the action of ejecting physical media such as a floppy disk, videocasette or DVD on a computer or media player. Eject Button was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Eject Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An emoji representing the cinema: a large screen showing the latest movies, available to the public. Displayed by most platforms as a film projector symbol, and previously by Google and Microsoft as a cinema screen with curtains. Cinema was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An icon of a outlined sun, used when decreasing the brightness of a screen. Appears smaller than the High Brightness Symbol. Dim Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Low Brightness Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An icon of a outlined sun, used when increasing the brightness of a screen. Appears larger than the Low Brightness Symbol. Bright Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “High Brightness Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Bars increasing in height, showing the strength of the mobile (cellular) phone signal. More bars signifies better reception. Antenna Bars was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Antenna with Bars” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

An icon representing vibration mode on a mobile phone, indicating that a phone should be switched to silent and/or vibrate mode. Displayed as a phone with either zig-zag lines or muted-bell icon on most platforms. Early versions of this emoji often used a heart alongside a mobile phone, as commonly seen in Japan. Vibration Mode was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A sign indicating that mobile phones should be turned off. Used in situations such as a cinema or live performance. Displayed as a mobile phone with the word OFF. Shown with a cross instead of the word OFF on Windows. Mobile Phone Off was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A circle shown with a crossed vertical line beneath it, used as a representation for women. Female Sign was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
A circle shown with a diagonal arrow pointing out the top-right, used as a representation for men. Male Sign was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A symbol commonly used to represent those in the transgender community. Used within the draft emoji sequence for the Transgender Flag emoji, and also given emoji presentation on Samsung devices. Shows as a plain text character on other platforms. Transgender Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Male with Stroke and Male and Female Sign” and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.
Multiply was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Multiplication X” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Plus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Heavy Plus Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Minus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Heavy Minus Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Divide was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Heavy Division Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The symbol for infinity enclosed within a circle or square. Originally encoded as a symbol to represent acid-free paper, this permanent paper sign was later given emoji presentation to form an infinity emoji. Infinity was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Permanent Paper Sign” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
Double Exclamation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Exclamation Question Mark was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Question Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Question Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Question Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Question Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Exclamation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Exclamation Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Exclamation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Heavy Exclamation Mark Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Just like a regular dash (hyphen), sometimes used in Asian character sets in the same way a – or — is used in latin character sets. Wavy Dash was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol for exchanging of two currencies. Most commonly displayed as a dollar symbol, with arrows to and from a yen symbol. Some platforms instead show banknotes and coins in yen, dollars, euros and pounds. Currency Exchange was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Heavy Dollar Sign was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol displaying of a rod with a snake entwined around the outside in a downward-spiral shape. Associated with medicine and health care services such as doctors or hospitals. A similar and related symbol called the Caduceus is frequently used in the United States. Medical Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Staff of Aesculapius” and added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The universal recycling symbol, featuring three arrows pointing clockwise in a triangular formation. The word “black” in the official name is due to this emoji existing as a unicode character before the current standardized emoji set. Recycling Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Black Universal Recycling Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A decorative symbol that appears like a golden flower, but found in all manner of logos, symbols, and patterns. This symbol forms part of the World Scout Emblem, amongst other uses. Fleur-de-lis was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A trident is a three-pronged spear, that appears similar to a pitchfork. Often held by Greek or Roman Gods in statues. Trident Emblem was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A name badge, used to identify oneself in a location that others may not know your name, such as a school trip, or a work conference. This tulip-shaped name badge is one of many designs commonly found at kindergartens in Japan. Name Badge was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A yellow and green shield symbol, called a Shoshinsha Mark. Must be displayed by drivers in Japan for one year after they receive their drivers licence. Similar to L-Plates used to identify learner drivers in other countries. Japanese Symbol for Beginner was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Used as an alternative to a check (tick) in Japan for a something that is correct. The opposite of an X (cross mark) for something wrong. Hollow Red Circle was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Heavy Large Circle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A check mark that displays with a white outlined appearance. Shows on most platforms with a bright green rounded rectangle or circle surrounding it. Android previously displayed this as an outlined blue check mark / blue tick. This emoji is not supported in Twitter names, possibly in an attempt to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Check Mark Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Heavy Check Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A checkbox showing a check mark inside the box. Not to be confused with the similarly named Ballot Box With Ballot emoji. This emoji is not supported in Twitter names, possibly in an attempt to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Check Box with Check was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Ballot Box with Check” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A thick check mark / tick displayed on some platforms in a handwritten style. Generally displayed in black, except on Windows where it is displayed in green. Commonly used in lists to signify completed tasks or verification of a statement of fact. Previously shown in red on Samsung and green on Google. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. See also: ✅ Check Mark Button, ☑️ Check Box with Check. Check Mark was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Check Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A large red cross mark, displayed in the shape of a letter X and similar to a multiplication sign. Cross Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Cross Mark Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Cross Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A curled loop, which is shown in black on most platforms. Displayed as a blue ribbon on Samsung devices. Similar to the Double Curly Loop but with only a single loop. Curly Loop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two curly loops, which represent a reel-to-reel tape recorder. Used as a symbol for voicemail on many phones. A variation of this logo is used by Free Dial, a toll-free telephone number by NTT in Japan. Double Curly Loop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Used in traditional Japanese music such as Noh or Renga, to indicate the start of a song. More specifically, the part alternation mark is displayed where the singer’s part begins. This symbol looks sort of like a lopsided capital M; or a rollercoaster track showing a dip, and then a drop off to the right. Part Alternation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Used in a similar manner to a regular * asterisk character but tends to be shown in a similar vertical alignment to a • bullet point. The eight spoked asterisk has both a ✳︎ text and ✳️ emoji presentation available on most platforms. Eight-Spoked Asterisk was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Eight Spoked Asterisk” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A star with eight points, that is commonly shown in orange, and for some reason, with only four points. See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names. Eight-Pointed Star was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Eight Pointed Black Star” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Used a decorative bullet-point, the sparkle has both a ❇︎ text and ❇️ emoji presentation available on most platforms. Sparkle was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Copyright was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Copyright Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Registered was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Registered Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A trademark symbol, the letters TM displayed after a word that is trademarked. Trade Mark was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Trade Mark Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A hash key, sometimes referred to as a pound key in the United States. Most commonly used online to make a hashtag (or hash flag) on social media sites. The Keycap Number Sign emoji is a keycap sequence combining # Number Sign and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Number Sign was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Asterisk emoji is a keycap sequence combining * Asterisk and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Asterisk was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Zero emoji is a keycap sequence combining 0 Digit Zero and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Zero was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit One emoji is a keycap sequence combining 1 Digit One and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit One was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Two emoji is a keycap sequence combining 2 Digit Two and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Two was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Three emoji is a keycap sequence combining 3 Digit Three and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Three was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Four emoji is a keycap sequence combining 4 Digit Four and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Four was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Five emoji is a keycap sequence combining 5 Digit Five and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Five was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Six emoji is a keycap sequence combining 6 Digit Six and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Six was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Seven emoji is a keycap sequence combining 7 Digit Seven and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Seven was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Eight emoji is a keycap sequence combining 8 Digit Eight and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Eight was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

The Keycap Digit Nine emoji is a keycap sequence combining 9 Digit Nine and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Keycap Digit Nine was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
The number 10 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap. Keycap: 10 was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Keycap Ten” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol showing the capital letters A, B, C and D. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to toggle capital letter input. Input Latin Uppercase was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Latin Capital Letters” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol showing the lowercase letters a, b, c and d. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to toggle lowercase letter input. Input Latin Lowercase was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Latin Small Letters” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol showing the numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable symbol input, as opposed to alphabetical or symbol input. Input Numbers was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Numbers” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol showing the following glyphs: 〒 (Japanese postal mark), 𝅘𝅥𝅮 (music note), & (ampersand, or sometimes an @ symbol) and % (percentage sign). Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable symbol input, as opposed to alphabetical or numeric input. Input Symbols was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Symbols” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol showing the lowercase letters a, b, c and d. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable alphabetical input, as opposed to numeric or symbol input. Input Latin Letters was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Latin Letters” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol representing Blood Type A. Displayed as the letter A on a red background. A Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter A” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol representing Blood Type AB. Displayed as the letters AB on a red background. AB Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared AB” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol representing Blood Type B. Displayed as the letter B on a red background. Sometimes used online to replace the letter C at the start of words in reference to the Bloods street gang's practice of turning words like cool into bool. This has expanded in some instances to starting any word with the letter B, or more specifically, this emoji which makes it more 🅱️lear that a letter has been replaced. B Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter B” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
CL is what shows on the CLear button of some older mobile phones. CL Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CL” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The word cool, shown enclosed in a square. This generally displays in a shade of blue, or blue-gray on most platforms. Used as a text decoration. Cool Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Cool” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The word free, shown enclosed in a square. Free Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Free” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A lowercase letter i, enclosed in a rounded square or circle. Implemented in apps or websites to indicate that help or further information is available. May be used as a logo for tourist information signage in a town or city. Information was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 under the name “Information Source” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The letters ID in a square. ID Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared ID” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The letter M in a circle, commonly used in to identify a Metro (subway, underground train) station in a city area. Circled M was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Circled Latin Capital Letter M” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
The word new, shown enclosed in a square. New Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared New” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The letters NG, shown enclosed in a square, which are an acronym for the words No Good. The origin of NG refers to bloopers shown during or after the credits of a live television show in Japan (known as NGs), but can be used in any field as a form of shorthand for no good. NG Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared NG” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A symbol representing Blood Type O. Displayed as the letter O on a red background. O Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter O” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The letters OK, shown enclosed in a square. Meaning Okay, denoting approval. The opposite of the Squared NG Emoji. OK Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared OK” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
P Button was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter P” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

SOS is the description for the distress signal in Morse Code. This emoji means SOS or “emergency”. SOS Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared SOS” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The word up with an exclamation point after it, shown enclosed in a square. Originally intended to denote leveling up in a game. Up! Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Up with Exclamation Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Vs Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Vs” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Means “Here” in Japanese, referring to a destination. Japanese “Here” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Katakana Koko” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Translates as meaning complimentary, or free of charge. For example, a drink that is given "on the house" to a regular customer. Japanese “Service Charge” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Katakana Sa” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Means “moon” or “month” in Chinese. Japanese “Monthly Amount” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6708” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This emoji means to own or posses. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Not Free of Charge” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6709” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This character translates as meaning a finger or toe pointing to indicate a certain direction. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Reserved” Button was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6307” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Denotes a “good bargain” in Japanese. Japanese “Bargain” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Circled Ideograph Advantage” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Symbol for a sale, or bargain prices in Japan (“cut prices”). Literally translated, this character means to cut or divide. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Discount” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-5272” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This means to lack, or have none of something. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Free of Charge” Button was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7121” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This Emoji means “prohibit, restrict or forbid” in Japanese. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Prohibited” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7981” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Japanese “Acceptable” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Circled Ideograph Accept” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This Emoji has two meanings. One meaning is “request” in Japanese. An alternative meaning is “monkey” in the Chinese zodiac. It is commonly used in Japan to denote an application form or contact information for inquiries. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Application” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7533” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Means “agreement” in Japanese. More literally, it means to unite, or join together. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Passing Grade” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-5408” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This 空 character means empty and available in Japanese. This is used in the context of an empty parking space or a vacant hotel room. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Vacancy” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7a7a” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Translated from Japanese, this means "congratulations" or "pray for happiness". Japanese “Congratulations” Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Circled Ideograph Congratulation” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Japanese “Secret” Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Circled Ideograph Secret” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Means “work” in Japanese.  This Emoji used to mean “open for business” and precedes business hours. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “Open for Business” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-55b6” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

This emoji means “full” in Japanese, usually used to denote “full capacity” such as a gas/petrol tank on a car or pre-paid phone card. CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters. Japanese “No Vacancy” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6e80” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Red Circle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Large Red Circle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Orange Circle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Orange Circle” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Yellow Circle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Yellow Circle” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Green Circle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Green Circle” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Blue Circle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Large Blue Circle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Purple Circle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Purple Circle” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Brown Circle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Brown Circle” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Black Circle was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Medium Black Circle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Circle was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Medium White Circle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Red Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Red Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Orange Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Orange Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Yellow Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Yellow Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Green Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Green Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Blue Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Blue Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Purple Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Purple Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Brown Square was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Large Brown Square” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.
Black Large Square was approved as part of Unicode 5.1 in 2008 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Large Square was approved as part of Unicode 5.1 in 2008 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Black Medium Square was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Medium Square was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Black Medium-Small Square was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Black Medium Small Square” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Medium-Small Square was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “White Medium Small Square” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Black Small Square was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Small Square was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A larger version of the small orange diamond emoji. Large Orange Diamond was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Large Blue Diamond was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
A small version of the large orange diamond emoji. Small Orange Diamond was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Small Blue Diamond was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Red Triangle Pointed Up was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Up-Pointing Red Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Red Triangle Pointed Down was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Down-Pointing Red Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A glyph that is used for kawaii in Japan, resembling the shape of a flower. Diamond with a Dot was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Diamond Shape with a Dot Inside” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A radio button user interface element, used in form fields with two or more choices. Differs from a checkbox, in that only one response can be selected. This emoji generally shows the on/enabled state for the radio button, with a smaller circle inside a larger outer circle. Radio Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
White Square Button. White Square Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Black Square Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A flag with black and white squares shown in a checkerboard pattern, used to signal the start or end of a motor car race. Chequered Flag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A triangular red flag on a post. Most commonly associated with golf, as shown in the flag in hole emoji. Triangular Flag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Triangular Flag on Post” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Two Japanese Flags, crossed at the base. Except on some Samsung devices, which have previously displayed two South Korean flags. Crossed Flags was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
Black Flag was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Waving Black Flag” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A white flag, shown waving on a post. Traditionally used as a sign of surrender, the meaning of this flag as an emoji is less defined. White Flag was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Waving White Flag” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

A flag with six colors of the rainbow, generally including red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple. Commonly used by the LGBT movement as a gay pride flag, or simply pride flag and seen at Pride events. In February 2019 misinformation was spread about a so-called "anti-lgbt emoji" which can be created using a combining character to show a black and white glyph like 🚫 on top of the rainbow flag. This is possible with any emoji on supported platforms, in the same way keycaps are combining characters. The Rainbow Flag emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏳️ White Flag, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🌈 Rainbow. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Rainbow Flag was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

A flag with horizontal pale blue and pale pink stripes with a single white stripe in the middle, used as a Transgender or Transgender Pride flag and commonly seen at Pride events. Approved in early 2020, some platforms added support while in draft status (Twitter, WhatsApp, Facebook). Coming to major operating systems by the end of 2020. The Transgender Flag emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏳️ White Flag, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ⚧️ Transgender Symbol. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Transgender Flag was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

A skull and crossbones displayed on a black flag, used on pirate ships, also known as a Jolly Roger. The Pirate Flag emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏴 Black Flag, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ☠️ Skull and Crossbones. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Pirate Flag was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

The flag for Ascension Island, which may show as the letters AC on some platforms. This same flag is used for St. Helena and Tristan Da Cunha. The Flag: Ascension Island emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇨 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter C. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Ascension Island was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Andorra, which may show as the letters AD on some platforms. The Flag: Andorra emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇩 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter D. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Andorra was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for United Arab Emirates, which may show as the letters AE on some platforms. The Flag: United Arab Emirates emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇪 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter E. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: United Arab Emirates was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Afghanistan, which may show as the letters AF on some platforms. The Flag: Afghanistan emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇫 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter F. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Afghanistan was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Flag: Antigua & Barbuda emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇬 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter G. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Antigua & Barbuda was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Anguilla, which may show as the letters AI on some platforms. The Flag: Anguilla emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇮 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter I. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Anguilla was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Albania, which may show as the letters AL on some platforms. The Flag: Albania emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇱 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter L. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Albania was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Armenia, which may show as the letters AM on some platforms. The Flag: Armenia emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇲 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter M. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Armenia was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Angola, which may show as the letters A and O on some platforms. The Flag: Angola emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇴 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter O. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Angola was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Antarctica, which may show as the letters AQ on some platforms. The Flag: Antarctica emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇶 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter Q. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Antarctica was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Argentina, which may show as the letters AR on some platforms. The Flag: Argentina emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇷 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter R. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Argentina was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for American Samoa, which may show as the letters AS on some platforms. The Flag: American Samoa emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇸 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter S. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: American Samoa was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Austria, which may show as the letters AT on some platforms. The Flag: Austria emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇹 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter T. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Austria was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Australia, which may show as the letters AU on some platforms. The Flag: Australia emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇺 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter U. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Australia was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Aruba, which may show as the letters AW on some platforms. The Flag: Aruba emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇼 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter W. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Aruba was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Åland Islands, which may show as the letters AX on some platforms. Flag: Åland Islands was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Azerbaijan, which may show as the letters AZ on some platforms. The Flag: Azerbaijan emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇿 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter Z. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Azerbaijan was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Bangladesh, which may show as the letters BD on some platforms. The flag for Burkina Faso, which may show as the letters BF on some platforms. The flag for Bulgaria, which may show as the letters BG on some platforms. The Caribbean Netherlands, a group of islands in the Caribbean Sea. The design for this emoji is shown as the flag for Bonaire on most platforms. The Flag: Caribbean Netherlands emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇧 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter B and 🇶 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter Q. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Caribbean Netherlands was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

Flag: Brazil was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The Flag: Bahamas emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇧 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter B and 🇸 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter S. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Bahamas was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Bhutan, which may show as the letters BT on some platforms. The Flag: Bhutan emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇧 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter B and 🇹 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter T. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Bhutan was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Bouvet Island, which may show as the letters BV on some platforms. This is the same flag as Norway. The Flag: Bouvet Island emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇧 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter B and 🇻 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter V. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Bouvet Island was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Botswana, which may show as the letters BW on some platforms. The flag for Belize, which may show as the letters BZ on some platforms. The Flag: Belize emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇧 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter B and 🇿 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter Z. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Belize was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

The flag for Canada, which may show as the letters CA on some platforms. The Flag: Canada emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇨 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter C and 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. The flag for Taiwan (officially Republic of China), which may show as the letters TW on some platforms. This Taiwanese flag is hidden from the emoji keyboard on iOS devices when the region is set to China mainland or (as of iOS 13.1.2) Hong Kong or Macau. Chinese-model iPhones will not display this emoji and will instead show a missing character tofu (☒) in place of the flag, as will iOS devices with region set to China mainland. Hong Kong and Macua only hide this emoji from the emoji keyboard. The Flag: Taiwan emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇹 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter T and 🇼 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter W. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Taiwan was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
